title: Estas empresas estadounidenses e internacionales -con presencia en Chile- ya subieron sus precios por los aranceles de Trump
content: Los aranceles del mandatario estadounidense ya están afectando a los usuarios, quienes ya están pagando más por sus productos.
resumen:
Los aranceles del mandatario estadounidense ya están afectando a los usuarios, quienes ya están pagando más por sus productos.

El jueves trajo una avalancha de datos que apuntan a un mismo resultado: los precios están subiendo.

Walmart declaró el jueves que los aranceles estadounidenses son demasiado altos, y en respuesta, está subiendo los precios. El director ejecutivo de Walmart, Doug McMillon, declaró en una conferencia telefónica sobre resultados: “Dada la magnitud de los aranceles, incluso con los niveles reducidos anunciados esta semana, no podemos absorber toda la presión dada la realidad de los estrechos márgenes minoristas. El aumento de los aranceles se traducirá en precios más altos”.

El 6 de mayo, Mattel anunció que subiría los precios debido a los aranceles. Su director ejecutivo, Ynon Kreiz, declaró a los inversores que, “en los escenarios actuales que estamos considerando”, en respuesta a los aranceles, prevé que entre el 40 % y el 50 % de sus productos se mantengan a 20 dólares o menos.

Trump amenazó a Mattel, diciendo que “impondría un arancel del 100% a sus juguetes y no vendería ni un solo juguete en Estados Unidos, y ese es su mayor mercado”.

Nintendo retrasó la fecha de reserva de su consola Switch 2 debido a la preocupación por los aranceles. Posteriormente, la compañía declaró que el precio de la consola no cambiará de los 450 dólares iniciales, pero que los accesorios “sufrirán ajustes de precio con respecto a los anunciados el 2 de abril debido a las fluctuaciones del mercado”.

Lin Tao, director financiero de Sony, fabricante de PlayStation, dijo “podríamos trasladar el precio” durante una presentación de resultados.

Las cadenas minoristas chinas Shein y Temu subieron los precios de algunos productos.

Dos sillas de patio publicadas en Temu y reseñadas por CNN tenían un precio de $61.72 el 24 de abril. Al día siguiente, cuando entraron en vigor los cambios de precio, su precio era de $70.17. En Shein, CNN indicó que un conjunto de traje de baño costaba $4.39. Al día siguiente, costaba $8.39, un aumento del 91%.

La directora financiera de Ford, Sherry House, dijo que la empresa espera aumentar los precios de sus automóviles en Estados Unidos hasta un 1,5% en la segunda mitad de 2025 debido a los aranceles.

El fabricante japonés de automóviles Subaru también ha anunciado que aumentará los precios en Estados Unidos para compensar el aumento de costos, alegando las condiciones actuales del mercado.

Un portavoz de Subaru of America declaró: “Los cambios se implementaron para compensar el aumento de costos, manteniendo al mismo tiempo una sólida propuesta de valor para el cliente. Los precios de Subaru no se basan en el país de origen de sus productos”.

title: Aranceles recíprocos de Trump dan ‘empujón’ a la BMV y alcanzan máximo histórico
content: Las acciones mexicanas han tenido un fuerte impulso tras el anuncio de los aranceles recíprocos de Donald Trump, al punto de alcanzar un máximo histórico.
resumen:
Las acciones mexicanas alcanzaron un máximo histórico el martes, impulsadas por un repunte posterior al Día de la Liberación y extendiendo una recuperación más amplia de la renta variable latinoamericana.

El hecho de que México haya salido relativamente indemne de los aranceles recíprocos del presidente Donald Trump ha sido un factor favorable.

La presidenta mexicana, Claudia Sheinbaum, destacó recientemente el trato preferencial que ha recibido México en las negociaciones y se mostró confiada en la relación de trabajo con los funcionarios de Estados Unidos.

Los activos de los países en desarrollo se han beneficiado en gran medida de la rotación que se ha producido en los mercados estadounidenses en medio de la agitación provocada por los aranceles.

La caída del dólar —el índice del dólar ha bajado alrededor de un 7 por ciento este año y se mantiene cerca de su nivel más bajo desde 2023— ayuda a los responsables políticos a reducir los costos de los préstamos, lo que impulsa aún más las acciones, según Greg Lesko, gestor de carteras de Deltec Asset Management, especializado en acciones de mercados emergentes.

El índice de referencia Mexbol subió hasta un 2.2 por ciento, hasta alcanzar los 59,735.43 puntos, su nivel intradiario más alto jamás registrado.

Las acciones de los países en desarrollo, que han subido más de un 8 por ciento en lo que va de año, superando con creces al S&P 500, que se mantiene estable en lo que va de año.

Este mes, los mercados bursátiles de Brasil, Perú y Chile también alcanzaron nuevos máximos históricos.

Las acciones mexicanas se cotizan a 12.2 veces sus ganancias combinadas a 12 meses, todavía por debajo de su promedio histórico de 10 años de 13.6 veces, según datos recopilados por Bloomberg.

title: Ecuador y el reto de capitalizar los acuerdos logrados tras la posesión de Noboa
content: La administración de Daniel Noboa debe aprovechar los acercamientos realizados en su posesión para atraer la inversión extranjera y generar empleo.
resumen: La posesión presidencial de Daniel Noboa el 24 de mayo de 2025 marcó el inicio de su segundo mandato y abrió una oportunidad para que Ecuador sea considerado comercialmente en otros mercados internacionales. A Ecuador arribaron 74 misiones de alto nivel y 19 organismos multilaterales. Uno de los logros más destacados fue la firma de una declaración conjunta entre Ecuador y Canadá para acelerar la implementación de un Tratado de Libre Comercio (TLC). Este acuerdo, negociado desde marzo de 2024 y finalizado en enero de 2025 tras seis rondas, abrirá el acceso a un mercado de 39,8 millones de consumidores. Sectores clave como flores, atún enlatado, textiles y autopartes se beneficiarán directamente. El secretario de Salud y Servicios Humanos, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., enviado oficial del presidente Donald Trump, reafirmó el compromiso bilateral para mantener las relaciones con Estados Unidos. La presidenta de Perú, Dina Boluarte, destacó la continuidad de más de 25 años de relaciones amistosas y de paz entre ambos países. El Perú Service Summit 2025, se realizará en Cuenca en junio de 2025. Llegarán empresas peruanas, entidades públicas, gremios y especialistas del sector servicios para fomentar el intercambio comercial, la internacionalización y la innovación. La presencia de delegaciones de países como China, Corea del Sur, Marruecos y Emiratos Árabes Unidos refleja el interés en fortalecer lazos con Ecuador. Ecuador ha intensificado las relaciones con Medio Oriente y Turquía, que también mandaron delegados. Recientemente, con Turquía, firmaron un Acuerdo de Cooperación Comercial que establece un marco para facilitar el intercambio económico y la asistencia mutua en materia aduanera. Turquía está interesada en sectores como turismo, energía y educación en Ecuador. Ecuador busca fortalecer sus relaciones diplomáticas con Marruecos mediante la apertura de una embajada. El objetivo es incrementar el comercio bilateral y las inversiones, así como la cooperación en seguridad, tecnología e información. Se han iniciado conversaciones para negociar un acuerdo comercial con Emiratos Árabes Unidos, lo que abriría la puerta para productos ecuatorianos premium como flores, banano, cacao, camarón, pescado y café.

title: Trump dice que UE quiere negociar “rápidamente” tras amenaza de arancel del 50%
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, dijo este martes que representantes de la Unión Europea (UE) han pedido "fijar rápidamente las fechas de la reunión" para llegar a un acuerdo comercial, ...
resumen:
El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, dijo este martes que representantes de la Unión Europea (UE) han pedido “fijar rápidamente las fechas de la reunión” para llegar a un acuerdo comercial, tras la amenaza del gobernante de imponer un arancel del 50 % al bloque por no ver avance en las negociaciones.

Trump escribió en su plataforma Truth Social: “Me acaban de informar que la UE ha llamado para fijar rápidamente las fechas de la reunión. Este es un evento positivo, y espero que, FINALMENTE, al igual que mi exigencia a China, abran las naciones europeas al comercio con los Estados Unidos de América”.

Trump advirtió el pasado viernes que impondría un arancel del 50 % a la UE a partir del 1 de junio por considerar que las conversaciones bilaterales no estaban “yendo a ninguna parte”.

También afirmó que se librarían del impuesto aquellas empresas que fabriquen sus productos en Estados Unidos.

El domingo el mandatario acordó en una llamada por teléfono con la presidenta de la Comisión Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, extender el plazo para lograr un pacto hasta el 9 de julio.

Trump dijo este martes en su mensaje de Truth Social: “Me sentí sumamente satisfecho con la asignación del 50 % del arancel a la Unión Europea, especialmente porque estaban siendo “lentos” (¡por decirlo suavemente!) en nuestras negociaciones con ellos. Recuerden, tengo la facultad de “LLEGAR A UN ACUERDO” para el comercio con EE.UU. si no logramos llegar a un acuerdo o si recibimos un trato injusto”.

Desde su regreso al poder, Trump ha adoptado medidas arancelarias contra sus socios comerciales, varias de las cuales puso en suspenso temporalmente hasta el próximo 9 de julio, en medio de la reacción negativa de los mercados.

Entre las que están en vigor se incluyen aranceles del 25 % sobre el acero, el aluminio y sus derivados, del 25 % sobre los automóviles y determinadas piezas de coches importados, junto a un arancel de base del 10 % aplicable a todos sus socios comerciales.

En el caso de la UE, ese arancel del 10 % podría llegar al 20 % una vez que expire en julio la actual pausa estadounidense.

Tras la imposición de los aranceles, EE.UU. ya alcanzó tratos comerciales con Reino Unido y China para rebajar los gravámenes y aumentar el acceso a esos mercados.

title: U.S. Oil Giants Fight Over Guyana’s 11-Billion Barrel Treasure Trove
content: This week, a private arbitration panel in London began hearing the arguments of U.S. supermajors ExxonMobil and Chevron regarding their rights to one of the world’s most lucrative oil projects.
resumen: U.S. oil giants are fighting over Guyana’s 11-billion barrel treasure trove. Chevron’s bid to buy Hess’s stake in the Guyana projects is being challenged by Exxon and CNOOC. A private arbitration panel in London began hearing the arguments of U.S. supermajors ExxonMobil and Chevron regarding their rights to one of the world’s most lucrative oil projects. Guyana’s Stabroek block has an estimated 11 billion barrels of oil in place discovered so far by the consortium of ExxonMobil, U.S. Hess Corp, and CNOOC of China. The high-volume, low-cost development offshore the South American country, which started production just five years ago, is already pumping more than 660,000 barrels per day (bpd) of crude. Exxon is the operator of the block with a 45% stake. Hess holds 30%, and CNOOC has the remaining 25% stake. In 2023, Chevron proposed a $53-billion deal to buy Hess Corp and thus take Hess’s assets in the Bakken in North Dakota and the 30% stake in Guyana’s offshore oil field. Production capacity in Guyana is expected to surpass 1.7 million barrels per day, with gross production growing to 1.3 million barrels per day by 2030, Exxon says. Guyana is now the third-largest per-capita oil producer in the world. The Guyana Stabroek block is estimated to have a breakeven oil price of about $30 per barrel. Chevron’s bid to buy Hess’s stake in the Guyana projects is being challenged by Exxon and CNOOC, who claim they have a right of first refusal for Hess’s stake under the terms of a joint operating agreement (JOA) for the Stabroek block. The arbitration initiated by Exxon and CNOOC has delayed the closing of Chevron’s bid to buy Hess by more than 18 months. The three-judge arbitration panel began hearings on Monday behind closed doors and is expected to rule within 90 days from the end of the hearings. Chevron’s deal to buy Hess has stalled. ExxonMobil finalized the $60-billion acquisition of Pioneer Natural Resources. In 2023, ExxonMobil, Hess, and CNOOC booked a combined $6.33 billion in net profit for their joint oil operations offshore Guyana. Hess’s share was $1.88 billion of this income. The combined net margin of the Stabroek block co-venturers was 56% in 2023. The Stabroek block co-venturers are expected to gain as much as $182 billion over the next 15 years from Guyana’s oilfields.

title: Wall Street sube con fuerza con el foco en las negociaciones arancelarias
content: Wall Street sube con fuerza este martes, en una sesión de vuelta al parqué tras el festivo del Día de los Caídos. Los futuros sobre los índices cotizan al alza animados por la tregua comercial de ...
resumen:
Wall Street sube con fuerza este martes, en una sesión de vuelta al parqué tras el festivo del Día de los Caídos. Los futuros sobre los índices cotizan al alza animados por la tregua comercial de Donald Trump a la Unión Europea (UE), al retrasar hasta al 9 de julio su anuncio de aranceles del 50%.

Ipek Ozkardeskaya, analista sénior de Swissquote Bank, valora que la situación es peor que hace un mes y que los aranceles no bajarán del nivel ‘universal’ del 10%.

Kathleen Brooks, directora de investigación de XTB, menciona que el mercado espera noticias sobre el progreso en las negociaciones comerciales entre la UE y EEUU y que Donald Trump ha dado marcha atrás tantas veces en los aranceles que el mensaje ha perdido fuerza.

Ozkardeskaya considera que los nuevos acuerdos entre EEUU y sus principales socios comerciales podrían impulsar aún más la confianza del mercado y llevar los índices a ambos lados del Atlántico a nuevos máximos históricos, pero aún está por verse si este optimismo perdura. Los datos económicos, especialmente las métricas de inflación, serán cruciales.

title: Remesas: ¿estrategia fallida?
content: Nos dicen que en Palacio Nacional ya no hallan a quién echarle la culpa por la fallida estrategia que se organizó para defender a las remesas y evitar que sean castigadas con el impuesto del president ...
resumen:
Banxico y sus proyecciones.

Nos dicen que en Palacio Nacional ya no hallan a quién echarle la culpa por la fallida estrategia que se organizó para defender a las remesas y evitar que sean castigadas con el impuesto del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump.

Usar el argumento de que ese cobro representa una violación a los tratados entre México y EU para evitar una doble tributación reveló un desconocimiento sobre el tema.

El Instituto Mexicano de Contadores Públicos, encabezado por Héctor Amaya, le corrigió la plana al gobierno federal, al señalar que dicha medida es para gravar sólo las transferencias de los paisanos indocumentados, es decir, el dinero producto de su trabajo, que no representa un ingreso directo para el Estado mexicano.

El desafío del Hot Sale.

En el arranque del Hot Sale 2025, se mantienen las expectativas de un consumo resistente en el país, pese a los pronósticos de un mal desempeño de la actividad productiva en los próximos meses.

Las promociones bancarias, principalmente de meses sin intereses, pueden ser una opción para los consumidores que deseen aprovechar la semana de descuentos en compras en línea.

Todas las instituciones bancarias se han volcado a ofrecer opciones de pago, sin importar el panorama pesimista.

Los grupos financieros, representados por Emilio Romano en la Asociación de Bancos de México (ABM) están conscientes de que, aún con un panorama retador, el consumo puede hacer frente a los aranceles del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump.

Inversión en almacenes.

En el transporte de carga es competitivo el Aeropuerto Internacional Felipe Ángeles (AIFA).

La empresa Talma, que dirige Vladimir Muñoz, acaba de invertir 9 millones de dólares en un segundo almacén de carga en esta terminal, que se suman a los 2.3 millones de dólares que invirtió en 2024 para ampliar su primer almacén.

La peruana es de los principales operadores de la región.

En México, Talma está en tres aeropuertos, y el año pasado gestionó más de 202 mil toneladas de carga aérea.

Con presencia además en Colombia y Ecuador, ya planea ingresar a Argentina.

title: Ayuso cifra el coste del ‘cupo catalán’ de Illa para cada madrileño: entre 900 y 1.500 euros
content: El Gobierno de la Comunidad de Madrid eleva el cálculo de lo que supondrán las medidas de Sánchez pactadas con los independentistas ...
resumen: El Gobierno de la Comunidad de Madrid, presidido por Isabel Díaz Ayuso, calcula que la propuesta de financiación singular para Cataluña, así como la condonación de la deuda pública, supondrá un coste para cada ciudadano de la región de entre 900 y 1.500 euros. La consejera de Economía, Hacienda y Empleo regional, Rocío Albert, desveló la cifra durante un desayuno del Nueva Economía Fórum. Albert lamentó que estas medidas costarán entre 900 y 1.500 euros a cada madrileño "para gestionar la fiesta independentista y que el señor [Pedro] Sánchez siga estando un día más en La Moncloa". Albert criticó que se adopten estas medidas que "quitan el dinero al resto de España para quedárselo los independentistas catalanes".

title: Celebra Trump solicitud de la UE para reuniones comerciales
content: Washington. El mandatario estadunidense, Donald Trump, calificó el martes de positiva la medida de la Unión Europea (UE) de establecer reuniones comerciales y dijo que espera que Europa “se abra” al ...
resumen:
El mandatario estadunidense, Donald Trump, calificó el martes de positiva la medida de la Unión Europea (UE) de establecer reuniones comerciales y dijo que espera que Europa “se abra” al comercio con Estados Unidos, aunque reiteró su amenaza de imponer unilateralmente condiciones si no se logra un acuerdo.

Trump escribió en su plataforma de redes sociales: “Me acaban de informar que la UE ha solicitado establecer rápidamente fechas de reuniones. Este es un evento positivo, y espero que ellos, FINALMENTE, como mi misma demanda a China, abran las Naciones Europeas para el Comercio con Estados Unidos de América”.

Agregó: “Recuerden, estoy facultado para “ESTABLECER UN ACUERDO” para el Comercio hacia los Estados Unidos si no somos capaces de llegar a un acuerdo, o somos tratados injustamente”.

Trump hizo los comentarios después de haber dado marcha atrás durante el fin de semana y retirar su amenaza del viernes de imponer aranceles de 50 por ciento a las importaciones de la UE.

El principal grupo empresarial italiano, Confindustria, pidió el martes a la UE que acelere los acuerdos comerciales con otros países mientras negocia los aranceles con Trump.

El presidente de Confindustria, Emanuele Orsini, dijo en una asamblea anual en Bolonia: “Después de actualizar los acuerdos con Chile y México, la Unión Europea debe concluir absolutamente el de Mercosur”.

Añadió: “Mercosur no es suficiente. Por eso debemos aspirar a alcanzar acuerdos con Australia, avanzar en nuestras negociaciones con India y los países de la ASEAN, y fijarnos en los 54 países de la Unión Africana que se han adherido a la zona de libre comercio”.

title: China no busca ser el "reemplazo" de EE.UU. como principal socio de Colombia, dice embajador
content: China no busca ser el "reemplazo" de Estados Unidos como principal socio comercial de Colombia, que firmó recientemente un importante acuerdo comercial con el gigante asiático que molesta a Washington ...
resumen:
China no busca ser el "reemplazo" de Estados Unidos como principal socio comercial de Colombia, que firmó recientemente un importante acuerdo comercial con el gigante asiático que molesta a Washington, aseguró este martes a la AFP el embajador chino en Bogotá.
El 14 de mayo, el mandatario izquierdista firmó la adhesión de Colombia a la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta, un multimillonario programa comercial y de inversiones de Pekín en el extranjero.
"China viene a ofrecer nuestra colaboración no como reemplazo de nadie, ni buscando quitarle espacio a nadie", dijo a la AFP el embajador Zhu Jingyang, en el marco de un encuentro con medios para profundizar sobre los alcances del acuerdo.
"Venimos para sumar, pero hay que tener en cuenta que también lo que está pasando con la política de la nueva administración de Estados Unidos es quitar, restar a lo que ofrecía al resto del mundo", en referencia a las amenazas de Trump de imponer aranceles a diversas naciones en medio de una guerra comercial.
China gana terreno frente a Estados Unidos como origen principal de las importaciones de Colombia. Entre 2014 y 2024 pasó del 18,4% al 24,9% del total, con US$14.700 millones el último año, según cifras oficiales.
En medio de la visita de Petro a Pekín, el Departamento de Estado advirtió que no dará luz verde a créditos del Banco Interamericano de Desarrollo (BID) para proyectos que tengan capitales públicos chinos.
El poder de voto en el BID es proporcional a los fondos que aporta cada país y Estados Unidos es el principal contribuyente.
"La reacción de Estados Unidos es lanzar amenazas limitando a Colombia a buscar nuevas alternativas", dijo Zhu.
Para el embajador, las advertencias estadounidenses son "trucos de intimidación" y "chantajes".
Dos tercios de los países de América Latina ya se han adherido a la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta, proyecto clave en la estrategia del presidente chino, Xi Jinping, para expandir la influencia de China.

title: La movida de Christian y Yuyo Daes para que Tecnoglass siga imparable con sus ventanas en la Florida
content: Invirtió USD 30 millones para quedarse con activos de Continental Glass Systems y asegurar mercado gringo mientras se preparan para montar una planta en EE. UU.
resumen: Christian y Yuyo Daes invirtieron USD 30 millones para adquirir activos de Continental Glass Systems, empresa con sede en La Florida, dedicada a la fabricación de vidrio arquitectónico y ventanería en Estados Unidos. Los hermanos Daes anunciaron la estrategia de internacionalización Tecnoglass, buscando un terreno para construir una planta de producción de marcos de aluminio y vidrio para ventanas en territorio americano, complementando la producción de su mega fábrica de Barranquilla. Tecnoglass, a través de su filial Energía Solar Windows, es responsable de cerca del 4% de las exportaciones totales hacia Estados Unidos. La empresa barranquillera tuvo ingresos de $954.000 millones en el primer trimestre, un 15,4% más que en el mismo periodo del año anterior.

title: Costco podría aumentar estos 5 alimentos por la implementación de aranceles
content: La política arancelaria que impondrá el presidente Donald Trump afecta el precio de diferentes productos importados al país ...
resumen:
La política arancelaria que impondrá el presidente Donald Trump afecta el precio de diferentes productos importados al país.
Ron Vachris, CEO de Costco, afirmó que los precios bajos se podrían mantener y “enfrentar este desafío aprovechando nuestro poder de compra global, sólidas relaciones con proveedores e innovación”.
Es posible que esta política arancelaria impuesta por Donald Tump, afecte los costos de algunos productos que tiene en sus estanterías.
Estos son algunos de los artículos que podrían irse al alza, consecuencia de los aranceles:
Extracto puro de vainilla: Actualmente tiene un costo de $13.99 por 16 onzas líquidas. El producto se elabora con vainas de vainilla importadas, principalmente de Madagascar, país al que se le aplicaría un arancel de 47% a partir de julio.
Café colombiano: De la marca Kirkland Signature tiene un costo actual de $22.49 por 3 libras. El país aún está sujeto al arancel del 10% impuesto a todos los países.
Aceite de oliva virgen extra italiano Kirkland Signature: Italia está sujeta a un arancel general del 10%. Actualmente se puede adquirir en Costco por $27.99 en una presentación de 2 litros.
Canela molida orgánica de Saigón Kirkland Signature: Los compradores pueden llevar el artículo, hasta ahora, por $19.99 por dos envases de 10,7 onzas.
Surtido de chocolate con leche Bouchard Napolitains: El precio actual es de $54,99 por 4 libras.

title: Trump elogia a la UE por acelerar las negociaciones tras su amenaza de un arancel del 50%
content: El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, se ha mostrado satisfecho con la reacción de la Unión Europea de acelerar las conversaciones comerciales tras su amenaza de fijar un arancel del 50% para ...
resumen:
El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, se ha mostrado satisfecho con la reacción de la Unión Europea de acelerar las conversaciones comerciales tras su amenaza de fijar un arancel del 50% para los productos procedentes de Europa.

Trump aseguró a través de su perfil en la red social Truth: "Me acaban de informar de que la UE ha llamado para fijar rápidamente las fechas de la reunión. Este es un evento positivo, y espero que, FINALMENTE, al igual que mi exigencia a China, abran las naciones europeas al comercio con los Estados Unidos de América. ¡AMBOS estarán muy contentos y tendrán éxito si lo hacen!".

El inquilino de la Casa Blanca ha recordado que cuenta con la autoridad para "ESTABLECER UN ACUERDO" comercial para los Estados Unidos si no se puede llegar a un acuerdo o si considera que son tratados injustamente.

El comisario de Comercio de la UE, Maros Sefcovic, trasladó a Estados Unidos su "pleno compromiso" con alcanzar un acuerdo que beneficie a ambas partes, después de que el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, amenazase el pasado viernes con imponer aranceles del 50% sobre los productos europeos a partir del 1 de junio.

title: ASEAN leaders agree tariff deals with US should not harm fellow members
content: Southeast Asian leaders reached an understanding on Tuesday that any bilateral agreements they might strike with the United States on trade tariffs would not harm the economies of fellow members, ...
resumen:
Southeast Asian leaders reached an understanding on Tuesday that any bilateral agreements they might strike with the United States on trade tariffs would not harm the economies of fellow members, Malaysia’s premier Anwar Ibrahim said.

Anwar, the current chair of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, said there was consensus during an ASEAN summit in Kuala Lumpur that any deals negotiated with Washington would ensure the interests of the region as a whole were protected.

The ASEAN meeting came at a time of global market volatility and slowing economic growth, and amid uncertainty over a trade war that has ensued since U.S. President Donald Trump’s announcement of sweeping “Liberation Day” tariffs.

Southeast Asia is among the regions hardest hit by the tariffs, with six of its countries facing levies of between 32% and 49% in July if negotiations on reductions fail.

“While proceeding with bilateral negotiations …, the consensus rose to have some sort of understanding with ASEAN that decisions should not be at the expense of any other country,” said Anwar, who on Monday said he had written to Trump requesting an ASEAN-U.S. meeting on the tariffs.

“So we will have to protect the turf of 650 or 660 million people,” he said of ASEAN.

ASEAN, a region with combined gross domestic product of more than $3.8 trillion, is in a precarious position in relation to the United States, which is the biggest market for the region’s exports, key drivers of its growth.

The 10-member bloc on Tuesday released a five-year strategic plan to better integrate its economies, citing challenges that meant “carrying on business as usual will not suffice”.

Tuesday’s meetings also included an economic gathering of leaders of the ASEAN, Gulf countries and China, which was represented by Premier Li Qiang.

One absentee was Brunei’s 78-year-old ruler, Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah, who was admitted to a Kuala Lumpur hospital after feeling tired, but was in good health according to his office.

At a dinner event late on Tuesday, China’s Li urged Gulf and ASEAN countries to remove trade barriers and expand liberalization in the face of rising protectionism and unilateralism.

ASEAN leaders also called for a temporary ceasefire in army-ruled Myanmar to be expanded nationwide, to enable warring sides to build trust and work towards convening dialogue.

Myanmar has been in crisis since its military overthrew an elected civilian government in 2021, triggering pro-democracy protests that morphed into a widening rebellion, with more than 3.5 million people displaced.

A devastating earthquake in March that killed more than 3,800 people led to a series of temporary ceasefires in affected areas of Myanmar, but the military government has continued air strikes and artillery attacks.

“We further called for the sustained extension and nationwide expansion of the ceasefire in Myanmar, as an initial step towards the cessation of violence,” ASEAN leaders said in a statement.

“We encouraged all relevant stakeholders in Myanmar to build trust towards convening an inclusive national dialogue.”

Anwar hailed “significant” engagement steps on Myanmar on Monday after last month holding a closed-door meeting in Bangkok with junta chief Min Aung Hlaing and virtual talks with the rebel-aligned shadow National Unity Government.

On Tuesday, Anwar said ASEAN leaders had agreed that the path forward was to engage all sides in Myanmar.

title: Want to destroy American business? Protect it, writes Carl Benedikt Frey
content: D ONALD TRUMP insists that tariffs will bring back jobs and revitalise American industry, and that short-term pain would be worth it for long-term gain. Yet history suggests they are more likely to ...
resumen:
Donald Trump insists that tariffs will bring back jobs and revitalize American industry, and that short-term pain would be worth it for long-term gain.

History suggests tariffs are more likely to steepen America’s slide into stagnation.

Oren Cass argues that the United States transformed from colonial backwater to continent-spanning industrial colossus behind some of the world’s highest tariff barriers.

Thomas Jefferson’s trade embargo in 1807, followed by the war of 1812 with Britain, jump-started American industrialization.

America’s early industrial gains owed far more to pirated British technology and welcoming European talent than to protectionism.

Trade restrictions ensured that small-scale textile mills were persistently inefficient.

These mills collapsed once trade resumed because they could not compete with superior British imports.

Samuel Slater, an immigrant from Britain, memorized the country’s textile-machinery designs and established America’s first cotton mills.

Francis Cabot Lowell secretly replicated British power-loom technology.

By 1980, Ford and General Motors recorded combined annual losses exceeding $1.3bn (over $5bn today).

Japanese car workers had become 17% more productive than American ones.

America’s share of global semiconductor production dropped from 57% in 1977 to just 40% by 1989, while Japan’s share almost doubled to 50%.

Japan’s manufacturing edge came not from unfair trade practices but from innovation: lean production techniques (like Toyota’s just-in-time system) and a talent for refining foreign inventions (Sony’s Walkman and VCR were adaptations of Western innovations).

Silicon Valley pivoted to innovation, design and software development.

It offshored assembly to low-cost East Asian manufacturers, especially in China.

Britain remained out of the European Economic Community until 1973, shielding domestic industries from competition.

Weak competition policy enabled widespread cartelisation, resulting in persistently low productivity growth.

Britain fell behind more open and competitive economies like West Germany and France, both of which had overtaken Britain’s GDP per person by the 1970s.

Three-quarters of American industries had become more concentrated than they were in the highly competitive era of the 1990s computer boom.

Spending on corporate lobbying has risen by almost two-thirds in real terms since the late 1990s.

Mr. Trump’s selective, sector-specific tariffs have set off a scramble for exemptions.

America may dominate electronic-design-automation software but Japan produces 56% of global silicon wafers, Taiwan makes 95% of advanced chips and China processes over 90% of critical minerals and magnets.

The tariffs in Mr. Trump’s first term ultimately caused a net loss in American jobs.

Duties on essential inputs, such as Canadian steel, only drive up costs and weaken American competitiveness.

About half of American imports directly support domestic manufacturing, and hence American exports.

In America, the five biggest companies average just 39 years old, and are all technology firms.

In Japan, the five biggest companies are, on average, 84 years old, 116 in Britain, 120 in Germany and 152 in France.

title: Why Japan sees President Trump's tariffs as a 'national crisis'
content: Although largely paused, President Trump's tariffs present a major threat to Japan's already flagging economy.
resumen: Robert Ward, the Japan chair at the London-based think tank the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS), states that since President Trump's "Liberation Day" tariffs, there has been alarm in Japan. Japan sees the U.S. as its most important export market, accounting for around 20% of all Japanese exports. Trump's tariffs present a major threat to Japan's already flagging economy. Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has described the situation as a "national crisis." Ishiba has come under pressure from Japan's opposition parties. Two important elections loom in July: the Tokyo assembly poll and the upper house of Japan's parliament. The LDP with its coalition partner, Komeito, has been a minority government since its poor performance in last year's general election. Japan's room for maneuver in tariff negotiations with the U.S. is limited. Japan's gross domestic product is only just over a 10th the size of the U.S. The U.S. is a major supplier of food, raw materials and mineral fuels to Japan, accounting for some 30% of Japan's overall import bill from the U.S. Japan needs to preserve its security relationship with Washington. The U.S. is Japan's only security treaty ally. Japan is unlikely to seek warmer ties with China. Tokyo's concerns about Beijing's intentions toward Taiwan have been mentioned. Intensifying Chinese intrusions into waters around Senkaku/Diaoyu Islands are also causing alarm in Tokyo. Japan could agree to increase imports of U.S. agricultural goods. Resource-poor Japan could also agree to import more liquefied natural gas (LNG) from the U.S., or to help fund an LNG project in Alaska. Some concessions on non-tariff barriers to the imports of U.S.-made cars into Japan also look likely. Ishiba promised to raise Japan's investment in the U.S. to "an unprecedented amount" of $1 trillion. Japan is the largest economy in the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) mega trade bloc. Japan's membership of Asia's other mega trade bloc, the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), is also strategically important for Tokyo.

title: India now leads iPhone exports to the U.S. as trade war reshapes supply chains
content: Apple is now exporting more iPhones to the U.S. from India than China for the second month running, a clear sign of shifting production priorities.
resumen:
India now leads iPhone exports to the U.S. as trade war reshapes supply chains.
Apple is now exporting more iPhones to the U.S. from India than China for the second month running.
Apple hit a major supply chain milestone in April 2025.
For the second consecutive month, more iPhones bound for the U.S. were shipped from India than from China.
Shipments from India surged 76% year over year to an estimated three million units.
Shipments from China fell 76% to about 900,000.
The export milestone is a clear shift in Apple's manufacturing strategy, but it comes outside the peak season for Pro iPhone models.
The surge in Indian exports reflects progress in Apple's plan to diversify.
The most advanced iPhones remain tied to Chinese production.
Previous years non-Pro iPhones came from China at this time of year.
The reversal reflects Apple's accelerated effort to reduce reliance on Chinese manufacturing.
The company began building out its Indian supply chain during the pandemic, but renewed U.S. tariffs on Chinese imports have added urgency.
In early May 2025, Apple CEO Tim Cook reiterated that most iPhones sold in the U.S. will eventually be assembled in India.
The ramp-up in Indian exports follows President Trump's latest round of tariffs, introduced in early April 2025.
Although iPhones were exempted from the initial measures, Apple moved quickly to shift final assembly operations to avoid supply chain risk.
Analysts believe Apple may have also front-loaded shipments in March, stockpiling U.S.-bound units ahead of policy changes.
India first surpassed China in iPhone exports to the U.S. that month, with the April figures reinforcing the trend.
Apple's Indian manufacturing operation, which now accounts for around 20% of its global iPhone output, still depends heavily on Chinese sub-assemblies.
Daniel Newman, CEO of Futurum Group, said the shift to India covers only the final step of the production process.
The vast majority of the sub-assemblies are all still in China.
India's current production capacity also remains limited.
U.S. iPhone demand averages 20 million units per quarter, and analysts at Omdia don't expect India to meet that scale before 2026.
President Trump recently imposed a 25% tariff on iPhones made in India.
China has also pushed back by restricting the export of high-end manufacturing equipment and engineering talent needed by Apple's Indian suppliers.
Manufacturing in India is also more expensive.
In April 2025, costs were estimated to be 5% to 8% higher than in China.
Apple has worked to offset that with tax incentives and streamlined logistics, including airlifting hundreds of tons of iPhones to the U.S. through "green corridor" programs earlier in 2025.
A green corridor is a fast-track export route that speeds up customs clearance.
Dan Ives of Wedbush Securities called the idea of shifting full iPhone production to the U.S. a "fairy tale," noting that Apple will continue investing in India regardless of short-term political pressure.

title: I’m a farmer, and I back Trump’s tariffs even if they will hurt me
content: The turmoil surrounding tariffs is just another factor in the mess of variables that will determine the success or failure of my enterprise.
resumen: Tim Keegan, a farmer in Mount Vernon, Iowa, and a member of the Global Farmer Network, is planting soybeans and corn this spring. He also has a small cattle operation. He is ready to put up with a trade war. About one-third of his soybeans, or byproducts of them, will leave his landlocked state, float down the Mississippi River on barges, and ship to customers abroad. A portion of his corn will also be exported. The worldwide hunger for beef is enormous. The prices they earn will depend on everything from precipitation in South America to the levels of consumer demand in China. Trump used tariffs aggressively during his first term and promised to use them again as he campaigned for his current one. He is encouraged by news of a limited trade deal with the United Kingdom as well as the apparent recent headway with China. Since the Great Depression, the federal government has supported farmers through direct payments, crop insurance subsidies, and loans. There are also subsidies for conservation improvement practices. 2005 government payments totaled almost $32 billion but were half that amount five years later. Total subsidies in 2019 were just under $23 billion, with $14.5 billion of that being authorized by the Trump administration due to tariffs (not including crop insurance subsidies). He accepted trade interruption payments last time and will accept them if they are offered again.

title: Trump's tax bill jeopardises clean power factory plans
content: Tax credit cuts in President Trump's budget bill have slowed the expansion of U.S. clean energy manufacturing, risking efforts to establish a fully American supply chain.
resumen:
Cuts to tax credits in President Trump's House budget bill are curtailing the rapid expansion in U.S. clean energy manufacturing capacity.

Biden's 2022 Inflation Reduction Act accelerated solar, wind and battery storage deployment and spurred new clean energy manufacturing projects. The act provides tax credits to clean power developers, incentives to buy domestic content and offers 45X advanced manufacturing production tax credits to suppliers that build factories in the United States.

Trump’s House budget bill proposes to speed up the expiry of the tax credits for developers and block the 45X manufacturing tax credits from going to foreign entities of concern (FEOC). The bill was narrowly approved by the House of Representatives on May 22.

Manufacturers have spent more than $321 billion in clean technology manufacturing since the inflation act was introduced in 2022. A total of 2,369 new clean energy manufacturing, utility-scale clean electricity and industrial decarbonisation facilities have opened since 2022, creating nearly 13,000 jobs in Texas and 12,500 in Georgia.

Many manufacturers are pausing expansion plans until the final bill is approved by Congress.

The proposed block on manufacturing credits for foreign entities of concern seems to apply to Chinese-owned companies and also companies “that have a licensing agreement with or receive any material assistance from a Chinese-owned company” and this would impact a significant amount of existing and planned U.S. solar manufacturing capacity.

For solar manufacturer Heliene, major amendments to the 45X production tax credits are the first concern, but the accelerated expiry of other tax credits would "also directly affect demand.” Heliene and Indian partner Premier Energies plan to develop the first module manufacturing chain to use U.S.-made polysilicon, wafers and cells but the final decision is still pending.

Manufacturers have already held back investments following Trump’s appointment as President, due to looming tax credit cuts and a raft of import tariff announcements.

Almost $8 billion in investment and 16 new large-scale clean energy factories and other projects were cancelled, closed, or downsized in Q1 2025.

President Trump has raised import tariffs to boost American manufacturing and gain leverage in international trade but volatile trade policies have deterred investors and U.S. clean energy manufacturers will likely face increased costs if the tariffs are implemented as proposed.

China dominates the global supply of solar components and imports into the United States from China and Southeast Asian countries, where many Chinese companies have relocated production, are subject to tariffs and antidumping and countervailing duties. President Trump has imposed an additional 30% tariff on imports from China as well as a 25% tariff on all steel and aluminium imports.

The inflation act led to a rapid increase in U.S. module production capacity, reaching 55 GW in May 2025, compared with just 8 GW in 2022. The U.S. is forecast to install around 40 GW of solar capacity per year in the coming years.

U.S. solar cell production capacity was just 8 GW/year in Q1 2025.

U.S. polysilicon capacity is currently around 26 GW/year but there is minimal wafer production capacity.

President Trump waylaid the burgeoning U.S. offshore wind sector by pausing the review of leases and permits and ordering the review of approved projects.

The Department of Interior rescinded a stop work order on Equinor's $5 billion Empire Wind project off New York.

Empire Wind will consist of 54 large offshore wind turbines of capacity 15 MW and the manufacturing facility will create up to 550 direct jobs.

title: Donald Trump steals Xi Jinping’s favourite foreign policy
content: In February Mr Trump halted graft investigations under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, blaming the law for erecting “excessive barriers to American commerce”. Though Mr Trump loves economic ...
resumen: China, a major economic and military power, often adopts a cautious and transactional approach to foreign policy, particularly in regions like the Middle East. This approach, focused on business deals and self-interest, has persisted under Xi Jinping, who presents China as a peace-loving giant to the world while emphasizing its global pre-eminence at home. China promotes prosperity through trade, technology, and infrastructure as a solution to regional conflicts, as seen with the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). China's foreign policy is often praised as "Chinese wisdom" by scholars. China has vetoed UN Security Council resolutions to impose sanctions on Syria. China's primary interest in Syria's civil war was the presence of Uyghur militants. China's response to problems is to call for mediation and suggest that Western intervention is the root cause. China favors opaque contracts and is a stingy aid donor. Donald Trump, the American president, shares a transactional approach to foreign policy, and is scornful of overseas aid. Trump praised Gulf Arab rulers for focusing on commerce rather than chaos. Trump halted graft investigations under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. China's economy is slowing, and BRI lending has peaked. China remains a major energy buyer and offers green technologies. Trump has given China cause to amp up the ideology, and push harder.

title: Proactive approach to trade talks in a shifting global economy
content: The global trade landscape is witnessing significant disruptions following Trump's tariffs, with countries navigating the fallout and rearranging trade relations in a post-American world trade order.
resumen:
The global trade landscape is witnessing significant disruptions following Trump's tariffs. Countries are navigating the fallout and rearranging trade relations in a post-American world trade order.

United States President Donald Trump's aggressive tariff offensive, initiated on April 2, has sent shockwaves through the global trade system. Rooted in the Grievance Doctrine, these tariffs have ushered in a period of uncertainty and instability. This approach lacks a sound economic rationale and risks upsetting the multilateral trade system. The Grievance Doctrine underscores a shift toward protectionism in US trade policy.

The actions of nations in response to the disruptions from these tariffs have led to a reshaping of global trade dynamics, revealing new political economic pressures at play. Trump's tariff-driven approach also risks undermining long-term investments, disrupting supply chains and straining relationships with trading partners, including Indonesia. The erratic decision-making and lack of a coherent strategy have put the US on a path away from a rules-based global trade system toward protectionism, with repercussions felt globally.

Indonesia finds itself at a critical juncture in the shifting global trade landscape following the aftermath of Trump's tariff offensive and the resultant recalibration in international trade dynamics. As the country adapts to a post-American world trade order fraught with new political and economic pressures, it faces substantial challenges outlined in the US Trade Representatives (USTR) Report 2025, which underscore areas of improvement across various trade-related aspects such as tariffs, non-tariff barriers, technical barriers, intellectual property protection and more.

The recent developments in the US-China Trade War, featuring a temporary 90-day "ceasefire" agreement, add another layer of complexity to Indonesia's trade strategies. The conflict, initiated by Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum in March 2018, triggered retaliatory actions from China, leading to escalating tensions and subsequent negotiations. Despite signing a Phase One Deal aimed at reducing tariffs and boosting US exports to China, disagreements over compliance have reignited friction, leaving Indonesia in a delicate balancing act amid threats of reciprocal tariffs and sovereignty concerns.

title: The Real Cost of Trump’s EU Tariffs
content: After a bout of relative market tranquility, investors were rudely awakened Friday with a barrage of new tariff actions targeting the EU and Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL ). Via Truth Social, Trump recommended ...
resumen: Trump recommended a 50% tariff on European Union imports starting June 1, 2025, and a 25% tariff on all iPhones made outside the US. The new 50% tariff replaces the 20% tariff on EU goods set in April. In 2024, the US exported $370 billion of goods to the EU, while we imported $605 billion, resulting in a US goods trade deficit with the EU of $235 billion. Conversely, we have a trade surplus of $109 billion with the EU in the service sector. The new proposed tariffs could significantly increase iPhone prices if implemented and fully passed through to consumers.

title: Republican senator admits Trump is Canada’s ‘adversary’ as DC delegation grovels in Ottawa
content: Months of provocative statements about the Great White North joining America as the 51st state in the Union, however, led the delegation’s lone Republican member to admit to reporters that the US ...
resumen:
Washington’s delegation to Canada seemed to have one message in mind: please keep taking us seriously.

The delegation was split between four Democrats and one lone Republican senator representing a border state — North Dakota. Other Republicans stayed home.

Kevin Cramer, the GOP “co-leader”, told reporters that Prime Minister Mark Carney centered him in his conversation with the group, given the senator’s relationship with the Republican US president.

He told reporters that he sought to encourage Canadian officials to reach a trade deal with the United States.

Cramer said after the meetings Friday, according to Punchbowl News: “I don’t want to get in Donald Trump’s way. There’s no [trade] deal that happens without his involvement. But at the same time [I want to] be an encourager to Canada and their officials and try to be a partner in some way.”

Cramer did not take a beating on Truth Social, even though he did lay the blame for the fraying of ties squarely on Trump’s shoulders.

“We have an obligation to stop the offenses,” the Republican senator told reporters, speaking of the United States.

“For the moment, the United States has become an adversary to the Canadian people because of the offense that so many have felt,” he continued. “What I would stress with the president would be, let’s keep our eye on the common adversary and how much stronger we can be.”

Cramer said: “I’m just here to say thank you, and then to encourage Canadians to take another look and give us another chance.”

Tim Kaine pitched Carney on his bill to block US sanctions on Canada.

Senator Jeanne Shaheen said that she hoped some of the “cracks” in the bonds between the US and Canada could be healed.

Carney, elected on a Liberal Party mandate to stand up to the US president, flew to Washington in early May after telling the BBC in an interview that Canada would negotiate with America “on our terms”.

The Canadian prime minister reportedly invited Claudia Sheinbaum to the upcoming G7 summit in Kananaskis next month.

Carney told Trump that Canada was “not for sale” during their meeting at the White House in early May.

The US president wrote on Truth Social that he presented Canada’s government with a $61bn price tag to be involved with the US’s proposed “Golden Dome” missile defene system, adding that it would be free if Canada relented and became a state.

“They are considering the offer!” Trump said.

In an address scripted by the Canadian government, Charles declared that Canada, under Carney’s government, would bond with “reliable trading partners and allies” — a clear warning shot for Washington.

He’d add that Canada’s government was determined to protect the right to “self-determination” for the country.

Charles said on Tuesday: “We must be clear-eyed: the world is a more dangerous and uncertain place than at any point since the Second World War. Canada is facing challenges that are unprecedented in our lifetimes.”

title: Carney invites Mexico’s President to G7 summit, raising hopes for sideline tariff talks with Trump
content: Prime Minister Mark Carney has invited Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum to attend the Group of Seven Leaders’ Summit in Kananaskis, Alta., next month, two sources familiar with the matter say.
resumen:
Prime Minister Mark Carney has invited Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum to attend the Group of Seven Leaders’ Summit in Kananaskis, Alta., next month, according to two sources.
Ms. Sheinbaum’s inclusion would provide an opportunity for talks with U.S. President Donald Trump on his protectionist tariffs and the future of North America’s trilateral trade agreement.
It would be the first three-way meeting between the leaders of Canada, Mexico and the United States since Mr. Trump took office.
The Globe and Mail is not naming the two sources because they are not authorized to discuss the matter publicly.
Mexico’s embassy in Canada declined to confirm the invitation or to offer comment.
Goldy Hyder, president of the Business Council of Canada, has been pushing the Carney government to invite Ms. Sheinbaum to Kananaskis.
Mr. Hyder said that Mr. Trump has fondness for Ms. Sheinbaum.
The U.S. President’s trade war on Canada and Mexico, which began in March, is discouraging capital investment in Canadian industry and has driven up costs for consumers and businesses.
The G7 summit is being held just outside Calgary.
On May 6, during a face-to-face visit in Washington with Mr. Carney, Mr. Trump told journalists he’s not sure the trilateral United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) is still relevant.
In an interview with CBC’s Power and Politics on Tuesday, Mr. Carney said there have been intensive discussions since then to work out a trilateral trade deal.
He indicated that a deal could be struck before September.
Flavio Volpe, president of the Auto Parts Manufacturers Association, said he thinks the fact that Mr. Carney has invited Ms. Sheinbaum to the G7 indicates that continuing trade talks between Canada and the United States are going well.
Fen Hampson, a professor of international affairs at Carleton University, said he thinks future trade talks with the U.S. might lead to a set of sectoral agreements – on autos, or steel – that could potentially even replace the USMCA.
Mr. Hyder said the Prime Minister’s invitation to his Mexican counterpart will help repair strained relations because of mismanagement by former prime minister Justin Trudeau and comments of Premier Doug Ford.
Mr. Hyder has meet Ms. Sheinbaum on two recent occasions.
Mr. Hyder expects Mr. Trump will push hard for a common position on how to deal with China and its unfair trade practices.
Canada and Mexico have each been holding bilateral talks in Washington with the Trump administration on defence and security matters as well as critical minerals.
Mr. Hyder said International Trade Minister Dominic LeBlanc was in Washington last week for talks on these issues with U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick.
Canada’s ambassador to Washington, Kirsten Hillman, said earlier this month she sees discussions on security – including the illegal distribution of fentanyl – and matters such as critical minerals taking place separately from the renegotiation of the USCMA, which is up for renewal in 2026.
The current U.S. levies on Canada that remain in effect include 25-per-cent tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminum, as well as a 25-per-cent tariff on Canadian-made vehicles, which applies only to the non-U.S. content in those cars and light trucks.
There is also a 25-per-cent tariff – which drops to 10 per cent on critical minerals, energy and potash – for goods that don’t comply with rules of origin in USMCA.
Canada responded with a series of countertariffs on tens of billions of dollars of U.S. imports.

title: European Midday Briefing: Stocks Edge Higher Amid Easing Trade Concerns
content: Consumer prices were 0.6% higher on year this month, down from 0.9% in April, according to EU-harmonized figures published Tuesday by France's statistics agency Insee. Economists had expected May's ...
resumen:
European stocks ticked higher Tuesday on easing trade tensions, with Germany's DAX hitting a record high. The European Union agreed yesterday to fast-track talks with the U.S., after President Trump on Sunday pushed back plans to impose a 50% tariff on the bloc.

Stock futures rose as markets returned following the Memorial Day holiday. All eyes will be on a consumer confidence survey for May. Another preliminary survey from University of Michigan released earlier pointed towards further weakening in consumer sentiment in early May.

The euro slipped against the dollar. The dollar fell as uncertainty over U.S. tariffs remains elevated. The DXY dollar index could fall to 98.000.

The 10-year Bund yield fell, and is expected to hover around 2.5% for now amid trade difficulties between the U.S. and Europe. A fall to 2.2% is possible "if there is lasting re-escalation". UniCredit expects eurozone government bond supply to decline in June but to remain above 100 billion euros. Eurozone sovereigns have issued 660 billion euros in government bonds year-to-date, equivalent to more than 50% of their total issuance objectives for the year. Yields on U.K. government bonds fell, tracking moves in eurozone bonds, as trade tensions ease. Long-end Treasury yields dropped as investors returned to the market with caution, awaiting May's consumer confidence survey.

Oil prices slipped with investors looking ahead to OPEC's meeting on Sunday to review its supply agreement. Lower prices in 2025 through 2026 could lead to an earlier and lower peak for U.S. shale production, Goldman Sachs said.

Gold futures slumped, extending losses seen on Monday. Signs that Trump is easing his stance on trade with the EU has dented safe-haven demand, ANZ said.

The U.S. Marines recently took position in a field on this sleepy Swedish island about 200 miles from the Russian city of Kaliningrad and fired their mobile rocket system.

Thyssenkrupp plans to make all of its divisions independent and open to outside investment, a major overhaul that aims to turn the German industrial group into a holding company after more than two centuries as a manufacturer. The company said Monday that it would start preparations to separate its materials-services and automotive-technology segments in the coming years and that its decarbonization-technologies unit would follow suit. It aims to retain a majority interest in its businesses in the medium term.

Consumer sentiment in Germany improved a little as wage expectations grew and views of the economic outlook calmed, despite the uncertainty provoked by President Trump's tariff policies, a monthly survey said Tuesday. The consumer-climate index published by research groups GfK and the Nuremberg Institute for Market Decisions ticked up for a third straight month to minus 19.9 in June's forecast, 0.9 points higher than in May. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal expected the measure a little stronger, at minus 19.6.

French inflation cooled more than expected in May, likely clearing the way to an expected European Central Bank interest-rate cut next month. Consumer prices were 0.6% higher on year this month, down from 0.9% in April, according to EU-harmonized figures published Tuesday by France's statistics agency Insee. Economists had expected May's rate to stay at 0.9%, according to economists polled by The Wall Street Journal.

To weather a trade war with the U.S., China is looking to its own consumers to keep the economy churning. Beijing has made bolstering domestic consumption a top policy priority for the first time, promising efforts to boost household spending. In one initiative this year, the government allocated 300 billion yuan, equivalent to around $42 billion, to expand a program that pays shoppers to trade in old vehicles or electronics for new ones.

Europe must maintain a steadfast commitment to open trade and bolster its legal and institutional foundations to raise the profile of the euro currency as confidence in the dominance of the U.S. dollar wanes, according to European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde.

President Trump on Monday said he was considering taking billions in grant money away from Harvard University and redistributing it to trade schools across the U.S.

President Trump posted on his Truth Social platform early on Memorial Day: "I am considering taking Three Billion Dollars of Grant Money away from a very antisemitic Harvard, and giving it to TRADE SCHOOLS all across our land".

Years before longtime Rep. Charlie Rangel became Harlem's longtime Democratic representative in Congress, he was an artillery specialist in the Korean War. In November 1950, near the North Korean village of Kunu-ri, the Chinese army encircled Rangel's unit. After being hit with shrapnel and leading dozens of soldiers to safety in a nighttime escape, Rangel was awarded a Purple Heart and a Bronze Star with valor.

The Air Force C-130 transport plane dipped down on the sun-baked airfield of this remote island in the northern Philippines, delivering a weapon system designed to give the U.S. an edge in the intensifying superpower standoff in the Pacific. The Navy-Marine Expeditionary Ship Interdiction System, or Nmesis, is an antiship missile launcher mounted on a remote-controlled truck. The dumbbell-shaped islet where it landed lies just 120 miles south of Taiwan.

title: Why Not All Hope Is Lost for the SPX Just Yet
content: The S&P 500 Index (SPX) tumbled last week as economic concerns mounted, but it could still see a short-term rally ...
resumen: The short-term sentiment backdrop leans bullish. Potential resistance at its 2024 close of 5,882 will be a key level for the SPX this week. The S&P 500 Index (SPX – 5,802.82) tumbled last week. President Donald Trump threatened to impose a 50% tariff on the European Union (EU). Levels for Friday to watch on $SPX include: 1) Election Day close at 5,782 and 2) 200-day moving average at 5,770. The SPX has an 86% chance of hitting that day’s close of 5,964 by this upcoming Friday. The SPX must overcome its pre-inauguration close at 5,996. The 5,978 level marks a 20% rally above the April closing low. Short-term SPY option traders saw predominant call volume last week. Option buyers on SPX components bought considerably more calls than puts relative to just a few weeks ago. The volume ratio is also now approaching a territory that has often marked peaks. title: Trade Crime Is Soaring, U.S. Firms Say, as Trump’s Tariffs Incentivize Fraud
content: President Trump’s steep global tariffs have supercharged efforts to evade them. Some U.S. companies say the government is ill equipped to keep up.
resumen: U.S. companies are receiving solicitations offering ways to avoid tariffs, with shipping companies, many based in China, offering solutions to U.S. firms that import apparel, auto parts, and jewelry. These proposals reflect a new flood of fraudulent activity, as U.S. tariffs on foreign products have increased sharply. Chinese firms describe their methods as valid solutions, but experts say these practices are methods of customs fraud, such as altering shipment information or moving goods to countries with lower tariffs (transshipment). The Trump administration said it would focus more on fighting trade fraud, but many American companies say the scale of illicit activity outweighs the government's ability to thwart it. These schemes are costing the U.S. government billions of dollars in tariff revenue annually. David Rashid, the executive chairman of Plews, said that unfairly traded products had filtered into supply chains throughout the United States. As Mr. Trump has raised tariffs to levels not seen in a century, companies say customs fraud is also reaching new heights. In his first months in office, Mr. Trump put a 10 percent tariff on most products globally, as well as a 25 percent tariff on steel, aluminum, and cars. Leslie Jordan, an apparel manufacturer, said fraudulent schemes were becoming "rampant" in her industry. Kush Desai, a White House spokesman, said that "instead of trying to find illegal workarounds to tariffs, foreign exporters would be better off telling their governments to negotiate a trade deal with the United States." John Foote, a customs lawyer at Kelley Drye & Warren, described the uptick in fraud as "a sign of entering a high tariff era." The U.S. government charges tariffs based on the item, its declared dollar value, and its country of origin. Schemes to evade tariffs include reporting a lower value for a product, misclassifying the item, and sending products to another country before they go to the United States. In April, Chinese exports to the United States fell 21 percent from a year earlier, but Chinese exports to Southeast Asian countries rose by the same percentage. An analysis by Exiger found that more than 3,000 companies in Mexico depended on Chinese shipments for 75 percent or more of their supply chain. Chinese companies are also marketing a method, "delivered duty paid," or D.D.P., that ostensibly reduces the U.S. importers’ legal liability for tariff fraud. Christopher Carney, an auto industry executive, said companies offering these schemes were operating with "a sense of impunity." The Department of Justice said trade and customs fraud would be a new priority under the Trump administration. Brad Muller, the vice president of marketing and government affairs at Charlotte Pipe and Foundry, said that the U.S. government was unable to stop Chinese companies from transshipping their products. Trish Driscoll, a spokeswoman for Customs and Border Protection, said that the department used enforcement tools, intelligence, and partnerships to combat tariff evasion, and, as a result of recent presidential actions, was now imposing the most severe penalties permitted by law. During the week of May 5 through May 9, Customs and Border Protection took in more than $630 million by reviewing more than 2,000 shipments detected for duty evasion. Importers are urging Congress to give the government more resources to go after fraud.

title: Japan Will Spend $6.3 Billion to Shield Its Economy From Trump’s Tariffs
content: Lawmakers approved a plan to help companies and consumers as officials bargain in Washington for relief from debilitating auto levies.
resumen:
Japan aprobó un paquete de gastos de $6.3 mil millones para "apoyar plenamente" a las empresas y los hogares afectados negativamente por los aranceles, dijo el secretario del gabinete Yoshimasa Hayashi en una sesión informativa. Los fondos reforzarán las finanzas de las pequeñas y medianas empresas y subsidiarán los costos de energía de los hogares.

El sector automotriz del país, la columna vertebral de la economía, ya se está tambaleando por un arancel estadounidense del 25 por ciento sobre automóviles y autopartes terminados.

Toyota Motor, la empresa más grande de Japón, ha proyectado un impacto de $1.3 mil millones en sus ganancias solo para abril y mayo debido a los aranceles. Honda Motor y Nissan Motor han pronosticado de manera similar fuertes caídas en sus ganancias. Nissan está considerando cerrar dos plantas en Japón como parte de sus esfuerzos de reestructuración. El fabricante de automóviles también planea trasladar parte de la producción de Japón a Estados Unidos para evitar los aranceles.

Los economistas han estimado que los aranceles automotrices más altos por sí solos podrían reducir significativamente la economía de Japón este año. Teniendo en cuenta las interrupciones más amplias causadas por las tensiones comerciales mundiales, los funcionarios han advertido que el crecimiento general podría reducirse a más de la mitad.

Antes de Japón, varios países reunieron fondos para ayudar a sus economías a hacer frente a la escalada de los aranceles. España dio a conocer un paquete de ayuda arancelaria de $15 mil millones el mes pasado. Canadá también ha destinado miles de millones de dólares para ayudar a sus trabajadores y empresas a capear el comercio turbulento con Estados Unidos.

El principal negociador de aranceles de Japón, Ryosei Akazawa, se reunió la semana pasada en Washington con sus homólogos de la administración Trump. Las conversaciones se han movido lentamente, estancándose al menos en parte porque los funcionarios de Trump han señalado que la principal demanda de Japón, una exención de los aranceles automotrices, no está sujeta a negociación.

El artículo fue escrito por River Akira Davis y Hisako Ueno.

title: Trump said his tariffs would ‘NEVER CHANGE’. Here’s a list of the times they changed.
content: Crikey does its best to keep up with the changes to policies that Trump said, in all caps, would 'NEVER CHANGE'.
resumen:
US President Donald Trump announced this week that the implementation of a 50% tariff on goods from the European Union would be delayed from its initially proposed start of June 1 until July 9 to allow for negotiations with the bloc.

February 1, 2025: US President Donald Trump signs three executive orders imposing 25% tariffs on all goods from Mexico and Canada (with some exceptions for Canada subject to a 10% tariff) and a 10% tariff on imports from China, to be imposed from February 4.

February 3: Trump agrees to a one-month pause on tariffs with the leaders of Mexico and Canada.

March 4: US tariffs on imports from Canada, China, and Mexico come into effect.

March 7: Trump once again delays tariffs on goods from Canada and Mexico.

March 26: The White House announces a series of tariffs on foreign-made cars and foreign car parts.

March 31: White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt insists there will be “no exemptions at this time” to the impending tariffs.

April 2: Trump announces “reciprocal tariffs” on all of the USA’s trading partners. This includes Australia, as well as the Heard and McDonald Islands, uninhabited Australian external territories that are home to our only active volcanoes.

April 4: Trump posts to Truth Social: “TO THE MANY INVESTORS COMING INTO THE UNITED STATES AND INVESTING MASSIVE AMOUNTS OF MONEY, MY POLICIES WILL NEVER CHANGE.”

April 8: In response to retaliatory tariffs from China, the White House announces an additional 50% tariff levied on top of previously imposed tariffs of 20% and 34%, bringing the total tariff on Chinese goods to 104%.

April 9: Trump announces he will pause the harshest of his tariffs for 90 days. A baseline tariff of 10% stays in place for most nations, and tariffs on China remain.

April 11: Trump confirms that tariffs on China will now be 145%.

April 14: Trump announces that he is considering a temporary exemption for automakers from the tariffs he’d previously imposed. “I don’t change my mind, but I’m flexible,” he tells reporters.

April 22: Trump says American tariffs on Chinese imports will come down “substantially”. “It won’t be that high, not going to be that high,” he tells an Oval Office press conference.

May 12: Trump agrees to a three-month cut on US tariffs on Chinese goods, down 115 percentage points to 30%. China drops its tariffs on US goods to 10%.

May 23: On the same day he proposes a 50% tariff on the EU, Trump threatens a 25% tariff on Apple’s iPhone unless the company brings its manufacturing jobs to the US.

May 25: Trump announces a pause on the proposed EU tariffs. The threat of tariffs on Apple, for now, remains.

title: Will Trump's tariffs on China raise prices at Ross? CEO says maybe. Here's what to know
content: Ross said President Donald Trump's tariffs could impact its profitability this year, potentially leading to price hikes. Find out more.
resumen:
Ross withdrew its fiscal 2025 forecasts on May 22, saying President Donald Trump's tariffs could impact its profits this year, according to Reuters.

The store said more than half its goods are made in China, which could lead it to potentially raising some of its prices if "inflationary pressures persist in the retail industry."

Ross' Chief Executive Officer Jim Conroy said the tariffs are expected to reduce earnings per share by 11-16 cents in the second quarter, according to the Wall Street Journal.

The Trump administration and China reached an agreement on May 12 to slash tariffs for the next 90 days while the two sides negotiate a long-term deal. This comes just weeks after the president raised more than 100% tariffs on China in a "tit-for-tat" reciprocal tariff battle originally intended to shift focus to American-made products.

Under the temporary new deal, Trump lowered the 125% reciprocal tariffs imposed on Chinese imports to just 10%. Trump's 20% tariff on Chinese fentanyl products will remain, meaning the U.S. tariffs on China will total 30% overall.

The deal does not apply to the universal 25% tariffs the president imposed on automobiles, auto parts, steel and aluminum.

Trump said he would raise the tariffs against China again if it does not agree to a final resolution after 90 days, but not back to the previous level of 145%.

title: Trade crime is soaring, US firms say, as Trump’s tariffs incentivize fraud
content: As President Trump’s tariffs have ratcheted up in recent months, so have the mysterious solicitations some US companies have received, offering them ways to avoid the taxes. Shipping companies, many ...
resumen: As President Trump’s tariffs have increased, so have the solicitations some US companies have received, offering ways to avoid the taxes. Shipping companies, many of them based in China, have reached out to US firms that import apparel, auto parts, and jewelry, offering solutions that they say can make the tariffs go away. The proposals reflect a new flood of fraudulent activity, according to company executives and government officials. As US tariffs on foreign products have increased dramatically, so have the incentives for companies to find ways around them. The Chinese firms advertising these services describe their methods as valid solutions. For a fee, they find ways to bring products to the United States with much lower tariffs. Experts say these practices are methods of customs fraud. The companies may be dodging tariffs by altering the information about the shipments that is given to the US government to qualify for a lower tariff rate, or they may physically move the goods to another country that is subject to a lower tariff before shipping them to the United States, a technique known as transshipment. The Trump administration said this month that it would focus more on fighting trade fraud, including tariff evasion. The administration is also trying to convince other countries to step up their own enforcement efforts, including in trade talks with Vietnam, Mexico, and Malaysia. Many US companies say the scale of illicit activity now far outweighs the ability of these governments to thwart it.
