title: Aranceles: ¿hay que cambiar
content: ¿Podríamos pensar medidas fiscales y monetarias agresivas para impulsar oportunidades, para Colombia? | Opinión | Portafolio.co ...
resumen:
La política arancelaria de Donald Trump representa un desafío para la economía global. El FMI ha reducido sus proyecciones de crecimiento global para este año y 2026 debido a la incertidumbre y la disputa entre las dos economías más grandes del mundo.

Algunos creen que el contexto actual generará oportunidades para algunos países. Se menciona que las políticas de EE.UU. podrían impulsar a Europa, como lo demuestra el anuncio de Alemania de crear un fondo de infraestructura, defensa y tecnología por 500.000 millones de euros. China ha anunciado medidas fiscales y monetarias agresivas para impulsar la actividad.

Se plantea la pregunta de si Colombia podría hacer lo mismo. Se sugiere aprovechar la posición geográfica estratégica de Colombia y diversificar su comercio internacional, que actualmente está muy expuesto a EE.UU.

Se argumenta que la guerra comercial dejará exhaustos a muchos gobiernos, lo que podría llevar a países europeos y asiáticos a buscar nuevos socios o fortalecer sus relaciones con ciertos países. Se destaca que países como Brasil, Chile y Perú tienen a China como su principal socio comercial, pero también están estrechando lazos con países de rápido crecimiento como India, Indonesia o Vietnam.

Se concluye que será necesaria una articulación entre el sector privado y el gobierno, lo que implicará que los empresarios deban cambiar su enfoque y el gobierno deberá implementar políticas de Estado a largo plazo. Se menciona que adherirse a la Ruta de la Seda podría traer oportunidades.

Daniel Velandia, Managing Director y Economista Jefe de Research de Credicorp Capital, es el autor del artículo.

title: Trump Administration Live Updates: Trump Delays Imposing 50 Percent Tariffs on E.U.
content: President Trump told cadets in a commencement address at the United States Military Academy at West Point on Saturday that they were the first graduates to serve in a “golden age” of the nation that ...
resumen:
President Trump said he would delay imposing 50 percent tariffs on all imports from the European Union until July 9 to allow more time for trade negotiations.

In a post on Truth Social, Mr. Trump said that he had spoken to Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, about his recent threat to enact the tariffs on June 1 if a trade deal could not be reached in the next week.

Mr. Trump has expressed frustration over negotiations with the E.U., saying that the union has been slow to offer trade concessions during a 90-day window to reach a deal that satisfies the administration.

On Sunday, Mr. Trump appeared to relent, at least for now.

Ms. von der Leyen, in a separate social media post on Sunday, said that she had a “good call” with Mr. Trump and had conveyed to him that the E.U. needed extra time to reach a trade deal. She said that talks would advance “swiftly and decisively.”

The extension is the latest turnabout by Mr. Trump, whose trade policies have injected substantial uncertainty into the global economy.

When asked if there was anything Europe could do to avoid tariffs, he had responded, “I don’t know, we’re going to see what happens,” adding, “they’ve treated us very badly over the years.”

Friday’s threat of 50 percent tariffs came after Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent met with European counterparts as part of the Group of 7 meetings in Canada.

Mr. Trump’s tariff threat against the E.U. came weeks after he agreed to partially pause the 145 percent tariffs he had imposed on Chinese imports.

European leaders have offered to reduce tariffs on industrial goods to zero if the United States does the same, and to increase purchases of U.S. energy, among other commitments.

In a post on Truth Social Friday morning, Mr. Trump wrote that discussions with the European Union were “going nowhere” and that he was recommending a 50 percent tariff on European imports as of June 1.

Mr. Trump also threatened a 25 percent tariff on imports of smartphones made by Apple and other companies on Friday, saying they should be made in the United States.

Economists at Oxford Economics said that if implemented, the E.U. tariffs and the phone tariffs, combined, would reduce economic growth by 0.2 percentage points, raise inflation by 0.2 percentage points, and increase the unemployment rate by a tenth of a percentage point.

President Trump continued his criticism of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for unleashing a deadly offensive against Ukraine instead of focusing on a cease-fire, writing on social media that Putin “has gone absolutely CRAZY” and was shooting missiles and drones into Ukraine’s cities “for no reason whatsoever.”

Trump who has largely focused on trade and other benefits to Russia if it ended its war against Ukraine, also wrote that Putin’s continued incursion could have dire consequences.

Speaking to reporters on Sunday, President Trump sounded an optimistic note on negotiations about the future of Iran’s nuclear program, which last took place on Friday in Rome and would resume “very soon,” he said.

Washington is demanding that Iran halt all uranium enrichment and dismantle all of its centrifuges.

President Trump on Sunday condemned the decision by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to unleash one of the largest offensives in Russia’s war against Ukraine, and said he was considering imposing more sanctions on Russia in response.

Mr. Trump said he was “not happy” with Mr. Putin escalating his attacks.

He added, “We’re in the middle of talking, and he’s shooting rockets into Kyiv and other cities.”

Mr. Trump continued criticizing Mr. Putin hours later, writing on social media that his Russian counterpart “has gone absolutely CRAZY” and was shooting missiles and drones into Ukraine’s cities, “for no reason whatsoever.”

Mr. Trump, who has largely focused on trade and other benefits to Russia if it ended its war against Ukraine, also wrote that Mr. Putin’s continued incursion could have dire consequences.

Mr. Trump’s remarks came after Russia carried out one of its largest drone and missile barrages of the war on Ukraine overnight, killing at least 12 people and injuring dozens across the country.

Asked whether he was considering levying additional sanctions against Russia, which he has threatened several times, Mr. Trump responded: “Absolutely, he’s killing a lot of people."

Mr. Trump, who has largely sided with Russia in the war, said he was “surprised” by the escalation, continuing to downplay the fact that it was Russia that initiated the war with an unprovoked invasion.

But Mr. Trump also had harsh words for President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine.

Mr. Trump said that Mr. Zelensky was “doing his country no favors by talking the way he does.”

President Trump sharply criticized President Vladmir V. Putin over Russia’s bombardment of Ukraine.

Trump also said he was “absolutely” considering more sanctions against Russia, something he’s threatened before but not gone through with as he sought to get Putin to agree to a cease-fire.

President Trump said that he is extending the deadline to impose 50 percent tariffs on the European Union to July 9, from June 1, following a request from Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission.

Von der Leyen said in a separate post that Europe is ready to advance trade talks “swiftly and decisively.”

Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, said on social media that she had a phone call with President Trump and that Europe was ready to advance trade negotiations “swiftly and decisively” but would need until July 9 to reach a deal.

The European Commission is the executive arm of the 27-nation European Union.

President Trump has expressed outright hostility to civil rights protections.

But in recent weeks, Mr. Trump has turned to those same measures — not to help groups that have historically been discriminated against, but to remedy what he sees as the disenfranchisement of white men.

The White House has defended its actions as part of an effort to put merit ahead of diversity.

On Monday, the administration said it had opened a civil rights investigation into the city of Chicago to see if its mayor or others had engaged in a pattern of discrimination by hiring a number of Black people to senior positions.

The Office for Civil Rights at the Education Department is investigating whether Chicago’s public school system is violating the Civil Rights Act with its “Black Students Success Plan,” alleging that it favors one group of academically underperforming students over others.

Last month, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission launched an investigation at Harvard University, alleging that the school had engaged in discriminatory hiring because it showed a significant increase in the percentage of minority, female and nonbinary faculty earning tenure over the past decade while the rates for white men declined.

In a letter sent to the university on April 25, the acting chairwoman of the E.E.O.C., Andrea R. Lucas, said she had started the investigation based on the university’s expressed desire for “demographic diversification of the faculty.”

title: La innovación y la especialización fortalecen a las empresas ante la incertidumbre económica
content: El anuncio del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump del 2 de abril de 2025 marca el cambio de dirección más importante de los últimos 50 años para el comercio internacional: una lista de aranceles g ...
resumen:
El anuncio del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump del 2 de abril de 2025 marca el cambio de dirección más importante de los últimos 50 años para el comercio internacional: una lista de aranceles globales.

La innovación es el antídoto para afrontar los aranceles. Un producto innovador ofrece un efecto sorpresa que aumenta la disposición a pagar más.

Los que tengan una brecha menor entre el coste de fabricación y el precio de venta del producto se encuentran inmersos en la trampa del bajo coste y están cada vez más expuestos a la incertidumbre.

Las empresas deben buscar siempre estar en la frontera. La mayoría de los directivos se encuentran atrapados en una inercia de enfocarse en la reducción de costos, lo que se convierte en una anorexia empresarial.

La expresión competitivo se asocia con la reducción de precios pero, en su origen, la palabra competitividad estaba asociada con retar los paradigmas existentes.

Al reducir costes, se acaba recortando los salarios.

La política de recortes aplicada durante el desarrollo del Boeing 737MAX hizo que el avión fuera menos seguro y, según los investigadores, contribuyó a los accidentes del vuelo 610 de Lion Air (2018) y del vuelo 302 de Ethiopian Airlines (2019).

El estallido en 2010 de la plataforma petrolífera Deepwater Horizon en el Golfo de México –y el posterior derrame de hidrocarburo más importante de la historia–, tuvo entre sus causas la reducción de costes.

Poner el foco en la innovación es una estrategia difícil porque basar el liderazgo empresarial en ese concepto requiere el esfuerzo adicional de dedicar –y pagar– tiempo para pensar.

Las empresas enfocadas en la innovación son capaces de absorber costes adicionales.

La cerveza mexicana Corona se posicionó con el precio más alto del mercado, compitiendo directamente con Heineken.

La inversión dedicada la investigación se ha desplomado en los últimos 40 años.

La innovación permite aumentar el nivel de sofisticación y el valor de los productos y, en consecuencia, que tengan mayores precios. Un precio alto es, en realidad, un derecho que se gana la compañía que innova.

Cada región del mundo puede, y debe, identificar cuál es su ventaja natural y encontrar la mejor manera de desarrollarla y aprovecharla para mejorar su posición frente a otras empresas de su sector.

Se identificaron cinco patrones que comparten las empresas y regiones que han logrado aumentar el valor de sus productos y, por ende, aumentar el diferencial entre el precio y sus costes:

1.  Enfocarse en los segmentos de alto valor de los diferentes mercados.
2.  Profundizar en la ciencia detrás del negocio.
3.  Expandirse hacia otros productos e industrias.
4.  Orquestar la cooperación pública-privada a través del diseño de una robusta política industrial.
5.  Buscar ideas en lugares punteros.

La imposición de aranceles universales por parte del gobierno estadounidense obliga a repensar las estrategias para competir en el mercado. Aquellas empresas que ponen el acento en unos costes de producción bajos no serán capaces de absorber los aranceles.

Promover el desarrollo económico a través de la innovación y la especialización, aumentando el valor de los productos y dando a sus productores una singularidad que les fortalece, debería ayudar a disminuir los riesgos provocados por esta guerra económica.

title: Precio del dólar en Colombia podría bajar en los últimos días de mayo: así de barato estaría para comprar
content: De acuerdo con expertos, la coyuntura local que hay tampoco hace que vaya a bajar mucho por el tema de déficit fiscal, reformas y otros detalles ...
resumen: El dólar en Colombia cerró el 23 de mayo en promedio de $4,165.45. El economista Andrés Moreno Jaramillo afirmó que el dólar está estable y ligeramente a la baja, lo que podría llevarlo a niveles óptimos de compra. El 25 de mayo, el precio promedio de compra del dólar en casas de cambio fue de $4.018,18, y el de venta, $4.146,36. Moreno Jaramillo no cree que el dólar rompa los $4.100. Sugiere que podría acercarse a $4.130 o $4.120 como máximo. El gestor de riesgo cambiario Antonio Lombana explicó que el dólar en Colombia está en una fase de consolidación estructurada. Desde el 25 de abril de 2025, se advirtió una posible visita del precio a las zonas de $4.200 y $4.150. Se observa un gap técnico originado por la guerra arancelaria impulsada por Donald Trump. El dólar mantiene su estructura alcista de largo plazo.

content: Asunción, 25 may (EFE).- Paraguay será sede de la 28 Conferencia de la Comisión Regional para las Américas de la Organización Mundial de Salud Animal (OMSA) en julio de 2026, anunció este domingo la S ...
resumen:
Paraguay será sede de la 28 Conferencia de la Comisión Regional para las Américas de la Organización Mundial de Salud Animal (OMSA) en julio de 2026.
La decisión se tomó en la 92 Sesión General de la Asamblea Mundial de Delegados de la OMSA que se desarrolla en Francia.
La ministra de la Secretaría Nacional de Turismo (Senatur) de Paraguay, Angie Duarte, aseguró que la designación de la sede de la conferencia es “una nueva muestra de confianza global” en su país que, además, es “reconocido como un importante exportador de carne de alta calidad”.
La 27 Conferencia de la Comisión Regional para las Américas tuvo lugar en la capital de Ecuador, Quito, del 25 al 29 de noviembre pasado.
La OMSA es una organización intergubernamental fundada en 1924 que lucha contra las enfermedades animales, con sede en París (Francia), y que cuenta con cinco oficinas regionales.

title: El rey de las monedas
content: El valor del dólar estadounidense como moneda de reserva internacional ha vuelto al centro del debate, luego de que la administración Trump ha expresado su preocupación por su supuesta sobrevaloración ...
resumen: El valor del dólar estadounidense como moneda de reserva internacional ha vuelto al centro del debate, luego de que la administración Trump ha expresado su preocupación por su supuesta sobrevaloración. El secretario del Tesoro, Bessent, advirtió que el dólar debería seguir siendo la moneda de reserva global, junto con una reserva estratégica de criptomonedas y el uso de “stablecoins”. Según Stephen Miran, el jefe del Council of Economic Advisers del gobierno, la intención sería depreciar deliberadamente el dólar, bajo la premisa de que su fortaleza ha contribuido a la desindustrialización de EEUU, al encarecer las exportaciones y abaratar las importaciones. Se busca mantenerlo –junto con las criptomonedas controladas por EEUU– como el ancla de intercambio de bienes, servicios y capitales en el mundo. Donald Trump amenazó con aplicar severas sanciones a los países que, como China o los BRICS, quieran competir con o dejar de utilizar el dólar. Declaró que “requerimos un compromiso de estos países de que no crearán una nueva moneda BRICS, ni respaldarán ninguna otra moneda para reemplazar al poderoso dólar estadounidense, o enfrentarán aranceles de 100%, y deberían olvidarse de vender en la maravillosa economía de Estados Unidos”. El rol del dólar como moneda de reserva internacional surgió hace 80 años, tras la Segunda Guerra Mundial con el Acuerdo de Bretton Woods en 1944 firmado por 44 países, incluidos EEUU, Reino Unido, Francia y Canadá. Este acuerdo estableció al dólar como ancla global, fijado al oro a una tasa fija de 35 dólares por onza, mientras que países signatarios fijaban sus monedas al dólar. EEUU garantizaba la convertibilidad del dólar en oro. En 1971, EEUU, reconoció que ya no podía sostener la convertibilidad del dólar en oro, y el presidente Richard Nixon puso fin al patrón oro. El dólar es la principal moneda de reserva internacional. Su hegemonía se ha mantenido gracias a su liquidez, estabilidad económica, la transparencia de los mercados financieros y su uso en el comercio internacional, en especial de los commodities. El euro es una alternativa que, sin embargo, carece del mismo alcance. Las crisis financieras de Grecia y Chipre, sumadas a la fragmentación de políticas, han dificultado su adopción universal. El fracaso del oro como respaldo monetario mostró los límites de basar un sistema financiero en activos escasos. Algo similar podría ocurrir con los países que intenta adoptar criptomonedas como reserva de valor, dada que la “escasez” es una constante en las criptomonedas, que no necesariamente acompañan la expansión de la economía.
tags: ['moneda de reserva', 'economía internacional', 'política monetaria', 'valuación de divisas', 'estabilidad financiera']

title: Aranceles de Donald Trump: las empresas que subirán los precios de sus productos debido a la medida
content: En un intento por proteger la industria nacional, las políticas arancelarias de Trump han generado un efecto búmeran.
resumen:
Desde que Donald Trump asumió su segundo mandato, la política arancelaria se convirtió en una pieza central de su estrategia comercial. El presidente impuso una serie de aranceles generalizados que han terminado por encarecer el costo de vida. Un arancel base del 10% para la mayoría de importaciones y un 30% sobre productos chinos son solo el inicio de un complejo rompecabezas económico que está afectando el bolsillo de millones de estadounidenses.

Empresas de todos los tamaños y rubros han advertido que no están dispuestas a absorber los costos adicionales, desmintiendo así la idea de que los aranceles castigan únicamente a los países exportadores. En realidad, quien paga el precio más alto es el consumidor final.

**Empresas que subirán los precios de sus productos debido a los aranceles:**

1.  **Walmart:** Su director ejecutivo Douglas McMillon dejó en claro que, aunque intentarán mantener los precios bajos, no podrán resistir la presión que generan estos nuevos aranceles. Se estima que el alza de precios será aún más notoria a partir de junio, afectando principalmente productos fabricados en China.
2.  **Mattel:** Su CEO Ynon Kreiz fue tajante: hasta un 50% de sus productos seguirán costando 20 dólares o menos, pero no todos lograrán mantenerse en ese rango. Trump incluso amenazó con imponer aranceles del 100% sobre sus productos.
3.  **Best Buy:** La marca advirtió que los “proveedores de toda nuestra gama trasladarán parte de los costos de los aranceles a los minoristas, lo que hace muy probable que haya un aumento de precios para los consumidores estadounidenses”.
4.  **Shein y Temu:** Temu anunció un ajuste de precios a partir del 25 de abril de 2025. Por ejemplo, dos sillas de jardín listadas en Temu tenían un precio de 61 dólares en abril, y hoy se pueden encontrar por 70 dólares.
5.  **Ford y Subaru:** Ford ya anunció incrementos de hasta 1,5% en sus precios para la segunda mitad de 2025. Subaru tomó una ruta similar, argumentando que los ajustes son necesarios para compensar los mayores costos.
6.  **Procter & Gamble, Stanley Black & Decker:** Procter & Gamble anticipó aumentos “probables” en algunas categorías. Stanley Black & Decker ya subió sus precios y anunció una segunda ronda de aumentos para más adelante este año.
7.  **Adidas:** Adidas anticipa precios más altos debido a la volatilidad arancelaria.

title: Indian benchmark indexes set to open higher after Trump delays EU tariffs
content: India's benchmark indexes are set to open marginally higher on Monday, after U.S. President Donald Trump extended the deadline for trade talks with the European Union, easing near-term tensions.
resumen:
India's benchmark indexes are set to open marginally higher on Monday. Gift Nifty futures were trading at 24,935.5 as of 8:09 a.m. IST, indicating that the Nifty 50 will open above its Friday's close of 24,853.15.

Trump extended the deadline for trade talks with the European Union until July 9.

The Nifty 50 has climbed 5.7% since early April. The index remains 5.4% below its record high of September 27, 2024.

Foreign portfolio investors purchased 17.95 billion rupees ($211.14 million) worth of Indian equities on Friday, bringing May’s net inflows to $1.64 billion.

India’s Q4 GDP data is due on May 30 and the RBI’s policy decision on June 6.

*   JSW Steel posts smaller-than-expected rise in March quarter profit.
*   Supreme Court of India dismisses Bharat Airtel arm Bharti Telemedia's appeal.
*   Linde India reports 12.3% rise in March quarter net profit.

title: How French industries are adapting to US tariffs
content: The trade war initiated by Donald Trump and his frequent policy shifts are plunging French companies into uncertainty. While some attempt to pass the increase in tariffs onto their customers, others ...
resumen: The trade war initiated by Donald Trump and his frequent policy shifts are plunging French companies into uncertainty. Some attempt to pass the increase in tariffs onto their customers, while others are beginning to rethink their value chains and increase their production in the US. Sylvie Grandjean, chief executive of Redex, attended the industrial machinery manufacturers' trade fair in Atlanta, Georgia, for several years. In the 2025 edition, which began on Monday, May 12, the increase in tariffs of 10% for goods exported from Europe, and up to 25% for cars and steel and aluminum products, decreed by US President Donald Trump in March and April, was a major topic of conversation. Redex manufactures measuring instruments for various sectors, including aerospace, and notably works with SpaceX, Elon Musk's space venture. Redex produces in France as well as in Germany, but 90% of its turnover comes from exports, including 15% from the United States. Its American subsidiary, with about 20 employees, has been based in New Jersey since the 1980s and focuses on customer services. The clients have agreed to absorb most of the additional cost of the 'Trump tariffs,' which will be reflected in consumer sales prices. Many French companies have been navigating in fog for weeks. They are trying to cope with the present situation while anxiously awaiting July 9, the end of the 90-day-pause decreed on April 9 by Trump, to determine the exact level of tariff increases. Alexandre Saubot, president of France Industrie, an organization representing major French industrial groups, stated that uncertainty and confusion prevail.

title: Trump’s tariffs cast $1.25 billion shadow over Victoria’s budget
content: A major economic downturn fuelled by US President Donald Trump’s trade wars could deliver a $1.25 billion hit to Victoria’s budget in one year, alternative government modelling shows.
resumen:
A major economic downturn fueled by US President Donald Trump’s trade wars could deliver a $1.25 billion hit to Victoria’s budget in one year, alternative government modelling shows.

State Treasury is forecasting a rebound in household spending and real wage growth this financial year, but last week’s budget papers also detail the significant risks to the economy associated with tariffs imposed by Trump.

The United States is Victoria’s second-biggest global customer for goods, narrowly behind China, making up 17 per cent of exports in this category last year.

Out of about $6 billion in exports to the US in 2024, pharmaceuticals and beef were the two biggest categories by value of goods shipped.

Victoria’s real gross product is forecast to grow by 2.5 per cent in 2025-26, but this figure could have been higher if the budget wasn’t expecting net trade to detract from the result.

In the 2023-24 financial year, Victoria imported $123.9 billion in goods and exported $37.6 billion, according to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

In sensitivity analysis in the recent budget papers, Treasury modelled alternative scenarios that could throw out the budget’s forecasts.

The analysis shows that if local spending does not grow as expected, and international growth stalls by as much as 1 per cent, Victoria would suffer a $1.25 billion loss to its revenue.

The government considers this scenario less likely than the economic conditions forecast in the budget papers, but the analysis highlights potential impacts of the 2025 US trade wars on Victoria.

The budget papers say: “Risks to the Victorian outlook from global conditions have increased amid a highly uncertain global backdrop.”

The US has imposed a 10 per cent baseline tariff on most imported goods. Most Australian products are subject to this tariff, with some limited exceptions and a higher charge on steel and aluminium.

In Treasury’s modelling of a worst-case scenario, global demand for exports would be 1 per cent lower than forecast coupled with sharp falls in confidence that weigh down investment and consumer spending.

If this occurred, the government is forecast to lose $1.25 billion from its bottom line in 2025-26, endangering Victoria’s expected $600 million operating surplus, the first since before the pandemic.

Another $564 million could be lost over the forward estimates, with most of the damage to the budget happening in the first two years.

By comparison, last year’s budget papers modelled a domestic slowdown and forecast a $600 million hit to the budget over four years.

In a more positive scenario modelled by Treasury, a higher-than-expected recovery in household spending in 2025-26 would add an extra $975 million to government income that year, adding up to $1.9 billion in extra revenue across the forward estimates.

Treasurer Jaclyn Symes said the government was looking at the impact of tariffs on pharmaceuticals and beef, but a lack of confidence across other countries would have the biggest impact on the economy.

The government is spending $35 million on programs to boost exports and support businesses with international trade. Another $18.1 million will maintain the state’s global network of trade and investment offices. A further $627 million is put towards delivering the Economic Growth Statement, a policy document released in late 2024.

Paul Zalai, director of the Freight & Trade Alliance and secretariat of the Australian Peak Shippers Association, said it was impossible to predict the full impact of US tariffs.

Hamish McFarlane, director of Te Mania Angus in south-west Victoria, said Victoria needed to maintain a relationship with the US because of America’s high demand for secondary cuts.

Victorian Farmers Federation president Brett Hosking agreed weather conditions were the biggest concern for farmers, but US tariffs had also caused anxiety.

The unemployment rate is forecast to rise to 4.75 per cent in the next financial year.

title: Una visión política y económica para el 2025
content: La semana pasada Desarrollo en Democracia (Dende) presentó su análisis sobre las perspectivas políticas y económicas para este año 2025, teniendo como telón de fondo las graves tensiones geopolíticas ...
resumen: La semana pasada Desarrollo en Democracia (Dende) presentó su análisis sobre las perspectivas políticas y económicas para este año 2025, teniendo como telón de fondo las graves tensiones geopolíticas que sacuden al mundo. El epicentro de estas tensiones se encuentra en las políticas de Trump que, por medio de la fijación de aranceles de importación a los productos fabricados fuera de los Estados Unidos, busca la reindustrialización de su país. Esta política es un palo en la rueda al comercio internacional que, según el Banco Mundial, ha sido el motor del crecimiento económico, la generación de empleo y la reducción de la pobreza, en las últimas décadas. Durante el periodo de la “hiperglobalización” desde el año 1990 hasta el 2008 el comercio global creció a tasas promedio del 6,6% y el PIB mundial al 4%. Hoy este crecimiento se ha debilitado y el FMI proyecta para este año un crecimiento global de apenas el 2,8%. Para dimensionar el impacto que tendrá este escenario en la economía paraguaya, tenemos que saber que de las exportaciones mundiales solamente el 10% son productos agrícolas y el 15% son combustibles y minerales; mientras que el 75% son productos industriales (la mitad productos terminados y la otra mitad componentes industriales). A este segmento industrial es adonde apuntan todos los cañones de Trump y por eso, a pesar de la turbulencia, los precios de las materias primas continúan estables y… eso es lo que el Paraguay exporta. Los shocks de Trump no están afectándonos por ahora, pero van a afectarnos directa o indirectamente en el mediano plazo. Ante esta incertidumbre global, el Paraguay debe priorizar más que nunca sus relaciones con los países de la región, específicamente con el Mercosur y muy especialmente con el Brasil. Nuestro desarrollo industrial es muy dependiente de nuestra integración a las cadenas productivas del Brasil y por eso nos preocupan las tensas relaciones diplomáticas que hoy tenemos con nuestro vecino. Hemos retirado a nuestro embajador en Brasilia a raíz del espionaje que ha tomado estado público, hemos recibido un fuerte golpe del Brasil con su rechazo a la candidatura de Rubén Ramírez a la OEA y lo más grave es que la negociación del nuevo Anexo C de Itaipú, que era una prioridad en el 2023, hoy se encuentra empantanada y sin visos de solución. En el frente interno a pesar del enorme ruido político y del prematuro electoralismo, la economía paraguaya cerrará el año con un buen crecimiento, que será del 3,5% según el Banco Mundial, del 4% según el BCP y del 3,6% según Dende. Sin embargo, en este buen escenario aparece en el horizonte una luz roja que es el déficit de la Caja Fiscal, que crece mucho más rápido que lo proyectado, que pone en peligro el cumplimiento de las metas de déficits definidas por el MEF y que dificultará la obtención del Grado de Inversión, por parte de una segunda empresa calificadora. Resumiendo, el mundo se encuentra en guerra militar y económica entre las grandes potencias y consecuentemente el crecimiento mundial será más lento en los próximos años. Nosotros para seguir creciendo tenemos que centrarnos en el vecindario, especialmente en el mercado brasileño, con quien hoy no tenemos las mejores relaciones diplomáticas. También para seguir creciendo tenemos que hacer nuestros deberes internos, cumpliendo este gobierno su promesa de “realizar todas las reformas pendientes”. Lo hizo creando la DNIT y el MEF y ya estamos recogiendo los frutos, pero las reformas más importantes y políticamente más difíciles, como las de la seguridad social, la salud y la educación, se encuentran pendientes. Nos hemos demorado en la realización de las reformas y hoy ya estamos sumergidos en un electoralismo desenfrenado, que hará muy difícil llevarlas adelante. Esta es nuestra visión política y económica para este año 2025.

title: Trump delaying 50% tariff on European Union
content: The president said Sunday he’s agreed to delay a 50% tariff on the EU that he threatened last week, after saying negotiations with the commission were “going nowhere.” ...
resumen: President Donald Trump has announced a delay on proposed tariffs on the European Union until July 9, 2025. This decision followed a request from European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. Speaking to reporters in Morristown, New Jersey, President Trump says that he had agreed to the extension as a privilege and noted that rapid trade talks would commence. The U.S. will delay implementation of a 50% tariff on goods from the European Union. The tariffs were set to begin June 1, but are delayed to July 9 now for negotiations. The president of the European Commission said she was ready to "advance talks" after Trump had said the 27-member bloc had been "very difficult to deal with." Trump’s European Union tariffs delayed. The 50% tariff on EU goods would have kicked in starting June 1, but Trump said his agreement to an extension sets the new date at July 9, 2025. If implemented, a 50% tariff would be higher than the 30% tariff on China. Trump posted on Truth Social Sunday evening, saying it was his "privilege" to have agreed to an extension, and said that von der Leyen said their talks will begin rapidly. US President Donald Trump speaks to journalists before boarding Air Force One from Morristown Municipal Airport in Morristown, New Jersey, May 25, 2025. Von der Leyen posted earlier on X that she had a "good call" with Trump. The EU and US share the world’s most consequential and close trade relationship. Europe is ready to advance talks swiftly and decisively. To reach a good deal, we would need the time until July 9. Last week, Trump said on social media that trade talks with the European Union nations were "going nowhere" and called for a 50% tariff to go into effect June 1. He said the 27-member bloc had been "very difficult to deal with." The EU has proposed mutually cutting tariffs to zero even as the president has publicly insisted on preserving a baseline 10% tax on most imports. Trump’s tariffs currently in place: 30% tariffs on China for a 90-day period, down from 145%. As high as 25% tariffs on Mexico and Canada. Universal baseline tariff of 10% on most countries. Trump is working trade deals with various countries in coming weeks. Trump has also placed various import taxes on autos, steel and aluminum and plans to do so on pharmaceutical drugs, among other products.

title: Tariff Uncertainties, Part 3: The Bond Markets
content: There are five important Treasury market anomalies to consider.
resumen:
The Treasury Bond market experienced significant volatility following the announcement of new high-tariff policies on April 2, with the market briefly appearing to be on the verge of collapse. The "queasiness" in the Treasury market was cited as the reason that tariff proposals were quickly put on hold on April 9. The market recovered, suggesting the relationship between tariffs and bond market turmoil had been demonstrated.

However, this conclusion is likely false for two reasons:

1.  **Scale:** The projected impact of tariffs on inflation or growth is small relative to the economy.
2.  **Treasury market anomalies:** The Treasury market has been behaving strangely for several years, unrelated to tariffs or trade policy.

There are five important Treasury market anomalies to consider:

1.  The Treasury market experienced its longest and deepest yield curve inversion ever, from July 2022 to September 2024, which did not lead to or predict a recession.
2.  This inversion was closely tied to reversals in Federal Reserve monetary policy, which had not happened in previous inversions.
3.  In September, the Treasury market broke a decades-long relationship between the Fed’s official interest rates and yields on Treasury bonds, potentially indicating the Fed's interest rate policy lever may have ceased to function.
4.  In early April, the Treasury bond market deviated from the usual crisis-response pattern, with a massive bond sell-off.
5.  Complex trading strategies like swap-spreads and “basis trades” have changed the tenor of the market in the direction of greater speculation, increased leverage, rising volatility, sometimes intensely crowded trades, and heightened sensitivity to external shocks.

The "Liberation Day" tariff shock set the stock market ringing like a bell, with the worst two-day decline in history, followed by a gain, and then more back and forth. Volatility exploded. The 10-Year Treasury Bond yield rose 64 basis points in two days, and Treasurys lost more than 5% in value in one week. Bond market volatility, as measured by the MOVE Index, surged more than 3 standard deviations above its recent average. Technical symptoms of bond market stress appeared, including a "significant" deterioration in liquidity. Contagion spread to global bond markets. The turbulence stirred fears that the Treasury market could seize up. The market deviated from the established crisis-response script.

Then, the storm blew over. The Vix returned to normal. The stock market recovered its losses rapidly. The Treasury bond market stabilized. Daily trading volatility returned to normal. The yield on the 10-year Treasury fluctuated on average just 4 basis points per day. Even the dollar was up 3%. The MOVE Index was back to its pre-April 1 average. The normal economic indicators are coming in with generally positive readings. Corporate earnings have been strong. The Fed reported that “economic activity has continued to expand at a solid pace.”

The real impact of tariffs, if implemented, would not likely be large enough to unhinge the massive Treasury bond market. The imposition of tariffs would amount to a scattering of one-time taxes across the economy. The Tax Foundation calculated that the 2018 tariffs resulted in tariff duties of about $200-300 per household annually– about 0.3% of the median household income. The Peterson Institute estimated that Liberation Day tariffs would cost consumers about $1200-1500 per household. The Penn Wharton Budget model forecast a similar reduction of about 0.4% of GDP in 2030. The Yale Budget Lab’s maximalist estimate of the impact of the tariffs included in the Liberation Day proposal was higher – $4800 per household, or about 2.1% of GDP.

The Treasury bond market is currently valued at 95% of U.S. GDP. It is the deepest, most liquid, and most efficient financial market in the world. It embodies an immense power to determine the price of credit everywhere. Treasurys set the rate of return on trillions of dollars of bonds held in the reserves of all major central banks, and trillions more in the portfolios of investors here and abroad – almost $29 Tn in all. The market trades more than $1 Tn per day.

The bond market is responding more to the Fed policy than to tariff talk. The Federal Reserve seems currently unable to move market interest rates in the desired policy direction. The "preconditions" in the bond market – especially the unwinding of the “basis trade” – were the major contributors to the market turbulence. Tariff talk was a trigger, but the large-scale market-clearing of Treasurys in a short time feels much more like a crowded trade unwinding than a response to the substantive economics of tariffs.

title: Harris warns US of risks with investigation of pharma, semiconductor sectors
content: Tánaiste Simon Harris has written to US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick to warn against US investigations into the pharmaceutical and semiconductor sectors.
resumen:
Tánaiste Simon Harris has warned the US administration of the negative consequences of imposing tariffs on imported pharmaceuticals and microchips.

Mr. Harris wrote to US Secretary for Commerce Howard Lutnick following the latter's instigation of two investigations examining whether the US' reliance on foreign imports in those sectors poses a risk to national security.

The outcome of the investigations could result in significant tariffs being imposed on pharmaceutical and semiconductors sold into the US from abroad.

In his letter to Mr. Lutnick earlier this month, Mr. Harris said Ireland and the US enjoys a "mutually advantageous economic bilateral relationship".

He acknowledged US foreign direct investment in Ireland is concentrated in a number of sectors, including pharma and semiconductors.

Mr. Harris stressed Ireland's approach on national security is "closely aligned" with Washington's, as he signalled a "desire to work closely with the US on economic security issues".

On pharma, he highlighted the focus of production is primarily on ingredients, rather than final products.

On microchips, he said Ireland has built an "extensive and technology-rich semiconductor industry".

Mr. Harris said Ireland's "highly-skilled, flexible workforce", and its "long-standing political and economic stability" attract US companies.

Approximately 60% of Irish pharmaceutical exports go to non-US markets, said Mr. Harris.

The supply chains between Ireland and the US have been built up over decades and "supported by the existing zero-for-zero tariff arrangement".

Mr. Harris said that another key factor of the relationship between the two countries was "our close regulatory cooperation", with a long-track record of pharmaceutical companies in Ireland securing recognition from the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

He said he was of the "strong view" that the Irish pharmaceutical sector "supports the health of the American people, and to impose tariffs on this sector risks not only the strides that need to be made in future innovation but also threatens the resilient supply chains needed to provide products to the US that have developed over recent decades".

In conclusion, Mr. Harris wrote: "I appreciate that you are undertaking these investigations due to national security concerns. Ireland's trade with the US helps support resilient supply chains and diversifications, and providing certainty of supply. Increasing costs on two strategic sectors that face growing competition from other regions will not aid in supporting US interests."

Minister of State for European Affairs Thomas Byrne has warned that if President Donald Trump follows through on his threat to impose a 50% tariff on EU goods, it would "effectively stop trade" between the two blocs.

Minister of State John Cummins said a US-EU trade war is not inevitable.

Social Democrats TD Rory Hearne said the task of concluding a trade agreement with the US was "extremely difficult" given what he termed the "completely erratic" behaviour of President Trump.

title: Apple has had few incentives in past to start making iPhones in US
content: Lashing out at Apple's plans to make most of its U.S. iPhones in India, President Donald Trump on Friday threatened to slap a 25 percent tariff on the popular device unless the tech giant starts ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump threatened to slap a 25 percent tariff on the iPhone unless Apple starts building the product in the U.S.
Apple has been building most of its devices in China for decades, investing tens of billions of dollars on massive factories.
Apple CEO Tim Cook said that most iPhones sold in the U.S. during the March-June period would come from India.
Cook said the trade war would end up costing Apple an additional $900 million during the March-June period.
Industry analysts estimated the fees would drive up the cost of a $1,200 iPhone made in China to $1,500.
Analysts believe if Apple could start making iPhones in the U.S., prices would soar to at least $2,000 and possibly as high as $3,500.
The disincentives for Apple shifting its production domestically include a complex supply chain that Cook began to engineer during the 1990s.
It would take several years and cost billions of dollars to build new plants in the U.S.
The price of an iPhone could triple, threatening to torpedo sales of Apple's marquee product, which generated revenue of $201 billion during the company's last fiscal year.
Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives estimated that the current $1,000 price tag for an iPhone made in China, or India, would soar to more than $3,000 if production shifted to the U.S.
Ives believes that moving production domestically likely couldn't be done until, at the earliest, 2028.
Ives predicted Cook would engage in a "game of negotiations" with Trump that would spare the iPhone from the 25 percent tariffs.
Apple executive Eddy Cue said that people may not need an iPhone 10 years from now.
Cook told investors that tariffs had a "limited impact" on the company in the March quarter.
Cook warned that it is "very difficult" to predict beyond June "because I'm not sure what will happen with tariffs."
Forrester Research analyst Dipanjan Chatterjee said that Apple continues to reap huge profit margins from the revenue generated by subscriptions and other services tied to its product, which collected $96 billion in revenue during Apple's last fiscal year.
U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick predicted tariffs would force a manufacturing shift.
Cook expressed doubt about whether the U.S. labor pool had enough workers with the vocational skills required to do the work.

title: Trump delaying 50% tariff on European Union
content: The president said Sunday he’s agreed to delay a 50% tariff on the EU that he threatened last week, after saying negotiations with the commission were “going nowhere.” ...
resumen: President Donald Trump has announced a delay on proposed tariffs on the European Union until July 9, 2025. The 50% tariff on EU goods would have kicked in starting June 1, but Trump said his agreement to an extension sets the new date at July 9, 2025. This decision followed a request from European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. Trump said he had agreed to the extension as a privilege. Trump said the 27-member bloc had been "very difficult to deal with." Trump posted on Truth Social Sunday evening, saying it was his "privilege" to have agreed to an extension, and said that von der Leyen said their talks will begin rapidly. Von der Leyen posted earlier on X that she had a "good call" with Trump. The EU and US share the world’s most consequential and close trade relationship. Europe is ready to advance talks swiftly and decisively. To reach a good deal, we would need the time until July 9. The core of Trump’s argument against the EU is that America runs a "totally unacceptable" trade deficit with the 27 member states. If implemented, a 50% tariff would be higher than the 30% tariff on China.

title: The bad economic vibes are causing more people to stock up on gold
content: Gold bugs are popping up on a wider scale, with global demand for gold bars rising 13% year-over-year in the first quarter.
resumen: The bad economic vibes are causing more people to stock up on gold. Demand for physical gold jumped 13% in the first quarter, according to the World Gold Council. Gold dealers say clients are worried about the dollar's decline, a debt crisis, and other scenarios. Marc Faber, a longtime investor, has been buying gold for decades and telling other people to stock up. He's eyeing a debt crisis, a plunge in asset prices, and soaring inflation. Faber said he buys gold regularly, with the metal comprising 25% of his overall portfolio. Global demand for gold bars climbed to 257 metric tons in the first quarter of 2025, up 13% in a year, according to the World Gold Council. Joe Cavatoni, a market strategist at the World Gold Council, said he believes concerns about the US dollar, economic weakness in the US, and the government's debt and deficit are several reasons gold demand is rising. Genesis Gold Group, a gold dealer, says it's seen intense interest in gold in the last few quarters. Jonathan Rose, the CEO of Genesis, says demand for prepper bars briefly surged after the presidential election and then jumped 20% in the first quarter of 2025. Rose said the number of the firm's clients who insist on holding physical gold has risen to 70%, up from 20% in past years. The price of bullion has climbed 25% in 2025. The S&P 500 is down by about 1% year-to-date. Goldman Sachs recently lowered its recession outlook from 45% to 35%, while Barclays recently removed its forecast for a mild recession. Michael Brown, a senior research strategist at Pepperstone, told BI this week. Michael Boutros, a senior technical strategist at StoneX, told BI. The World Gold Council's Cavatoni added.

title: The weekender: out of the deficit frying pan, back into the tariff fire
content: Ending Tariff Carousel. The tariff carousel just cranked back into overdrive, and markets—lulled into a false sense of calm—snapped back to attention. President Trum ...
resumen: The tariff carousel cranked back into overdrive, and markets snapped back to attention. President Trump threatened a 50% tariff on European Union imports and signaled that iPhones assembled outside U.S. borders could face punitive levies. Apple got the first slap, sliding over 2%. U.S. and European equities sold off, though not in panic mode. Treasuries reversed earlier weakness, with 10-year yields sinking back to 4.51% and 30-year yields retreating below 5.04%. Gold surged over 2%, while haven currencies—yen and Swiss franc—squeezed higher, even the euro rallied. After a week dominated by fears over the U.S. fiscal trajectory—courtesy of a CBO-scored $500 billion annual deficit injection for the next four years—the market barely had time to digest the long-term damage before Trump reignited the trade war. The clearest signal wasn’t even in yields—it was in the sell America unison: stocks tanked, the dollar sagged, and safe havens went rogue as risk smouldered with intent. Finance chiefs from the world’s most powerful economies issued a joint statement so sanitized it could have been written in advance by AI. EU officials reportedly pushed hard for stronger language but ran into the same American wall that now seems to prefer tariffs as diplomacy by other means. Trump wasn’t looking for a deal, he said, and signaled further escalation if Europe didn’t play ball. Apple was just the beginning. Samsung, other handset makers, and likely pharma firms are all potentially in the crosshairs. The U.S. is constructing a tariff scaffold around its own economy—and the world is watching whether it’s scaffolding for renovation or a gallows for the dollar’s credibility. The U.S. is heading back to the tariff well while piling on trillions in new deficits—without the growth bang to offset the fiscal buck. Germany is now ramping up fiscal support that’s set to bite in 2026. Eurozone balance of payments data shows massive repatriation of foreign equities back into euro assets—nearly €40 billion in March alone. The euro, increasingly, is the only viable liquid alternative to a dollar that looks overvalued, overleveraged, and overexposed to political risk. In Asia, the yen is regaining relevance as rising inflation and hawkish signals from the BoJ put a July rate hike firmly on the table. Japanese core CPI just hit its fastest pace in two years. The markets’ behaviour on Friday showed a fragile equilibrium. Markets are navigating blindfolded through a minefield where the next detonation could come from tariffs, deficits, central bank missteps, or geopolitical drift. The U.S. appears determined to go it alone, walling itself off with trade barriers, while the rest of the world tentatively sketches out new alignments. The fear isn’t just inflation or rates or trade—it’s irrelevance. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index is down another 0.8% on Friday and more than 7% on the year. CFTC data show hedge funds are still stacked net-short. Trump’s threat to slap a 50% levy on EU imports has traders re-pricing everything from recession odds to risk premia. The result? A broad G10 stampede higher. Kiwi and Aussie dollars vaulted over 1%; Canada’s loonie clawed back to seven-month highs. Traditional safe havens like the yen and Swiss franc flexed as capital tiptoed out of U.S. assets. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent hinted at “big” trade deals in the pipeline. Senate wrangling over a tax-and-spend bill could stuff hundreds of billions more into the deficit while bumping the debt ceiling right up against a late-summer deadline. Gold prices are hovering around $3,356 as of May 23. Consensus forecasts now peg gold climbing to $3,700 per troy ounce by the end of 2025. Since March, gold holdings have surged. Central banks are building long-term positions. Developed economies have 70% or more of their reserves in gold. Emerging market central banks are still underweight. China has less than 10% of its reserves in gold.

title: Long-term bond yields surge around the world
content: WASHINGTON: Around the world, yields on longer-dated sovereign debt have soared as investors question the ability of governments to cover massive budget deficits.
resumen:
Around the world, yields on longer-dated sovereign debt have soared as investors question the ability of governments to cover massive budget deficits.

In the United States, 30-year bond yields last week approached levels last seen in 2007 as President Donald Trump’s tax bill is poised to swell the budget deficit.

Those in Japan exceeded the highest on record in data since 1999, with auctions in both countries drawing tepid demand.

Long-dated bonds in Britain, Germany and Australia also faced selling pressure.

Banks in China lowered their benchmark lending rates for the first time in seven months, and Australia’s central bank cut its key interest rate for a second time this year in a bid to mitigate the impact of US tariffs.

A pullback by central banks and pension funds from bond markets has marginalised a once-dependable source of funding.

The giants of corporate America, from Pfizer Inc to Alphabet Inc, are borrowing in euros like never before as the anxiety triggered by Trump’s tariff threats pushes them to hunt for alternative funding avenues in case their home market freezes up.

In addition to the decisions by Australian and Chinese banks, Iceland, Jamaica, Sri Lanka, Egypt and Indonesia lowered rates.

Officials in Angola, Nigeria, Zambia, Ghana and Paraguay kept borrowing costs unchanged.

Europe UK inflation jumped more than forecast to its highest rate in over a year.

Services inflation accelerated to 5.4% from 4.7%.

Private-sector activity in the euro area unexpectedly shrank in May as services recorded their worst performance in 16 months.

Bulgaria is close to clearing a major hurdle toward euro adoption, putting the Black Sea nation on course to join the currency area next year.

US Chinese shipments of Apple Inc’s iPhone and other mobile devices to the United States dived to their lowest levels since 2011 in April.

Mexico’s annual inflation accelerated more than expected early this month in a report that likely won’t deter central bankers from cutting interest rates again in June.

Argentina’s economy grew less than expected in March.

title: President Trump Vows to Prioritize American Interests in World Trade Week Proclamation
content: President Trump's proclamation for World Trade Week focuses on prioritizing American workers and industries in trade policies.
resumen: Como parte de la observancia anual de la Semana Mundial del Comercio, el presidente Donald Trump enfatizó recientemente el enfoque de su administración en la recalibración de las políticas comerciales para priorizar los intereses estadounidenses. En una proclamación, Trump destacó medidas destinadas a fomentar relaciones comerciales equilibradas y recíprocas y expresó su apoyo a los trabajadores estadounidenses que, según él, han sido marginados previamente debido a la globalización. "Durante demasiado tiempo, las élites globalistas vendieron al trabajador estadounidense y permitieron que otros países tomaran injustamente nuestras fábricas, nuestros empleos y nuestros sueños. Esos días terminaron", declaró el Presidente en una proclamación emitida por la Casa Blanca. El Presidente subrayó su dedicación a la creación de un entorno más propicio para la creación de empleo nacional y el fortalecimiento industrial. Señaló que su administración ha sido proactiva en revertir la tendencia de la deslocalización, mediante la promulgación de aranceles y otras medidas comerciales. "Mi Administración está entregando ese futuro", dijo Trump, refiriéndose a una visión que articuló mientras hacía campaña para el cargo. "Desde que asumí el cargo, he tomado medidas para proporcionar una vida mejor para todos los estadounidenses y especialmente para los millones de estadounidenses que quedaron en el camino a medida que los empleos se enviaban al extranjero", según la Casa Blanca. La proclamación de la Casa Blanca también detalló los movimientos de política comercial destinados a frenar la importación de fentanilo y a promover la competitividad estadounidense en el extranjero. Elogió la introducción de nuevos acuerdos comerciales, como el acuerdo comercial entre Estados Unidos y el Reino Unido, que buscan crear oportunidades para las empresas estadounidenses a nivel internacional. El Presidente se comprometió a combatir las prácticas comerciales desleales que afectan a una amplia franja de la población estadounidense, desde "agricultores y pescadores hasta empresarios y todos los demás", según la Casa Blanca. Trump expresó una firme determinación de perpetuar una estrategia de "Estados Unidos primero" en todas las negociaciones comerciales y el desarrollo de políticas. "Como Presidente, siempre pondré los intereses de Estados Unidos primero", afirmó. "Juntos, construiremos una nueva Edad de Oro para Estados Unidos con un fuerte crecimiento económico y políticas comerciales de Estados Unidos primero que protejan a nuestros trabajadores, fortalezcan nuestras industrias y desbloqueen el Sueño Americano para todos los ciudadanos". El domingo pasado hasta ayer fueron designados como la Semana Mundial del Comercio, invitando a la celebración de las contribuciones del comercio estadounidense bajo la directiva de Trump, según lo detallado por la Casa Blanca.

title: Trump Agrees To Extend 50% Tariffs On Europe Until July 9: 'It Was My Privilege To Do So'
content: Trump agreed to extend tariff deadline to July 9, 2025 after receiving call from Ursula von der Leyen, amid ongoing trade tensions between US and EU.
resumen: Donald Trump announced on Sunday that he received a call from Ursula von der Leyen, the President of the European Commission, requesting an extension on the impending 50% tariff deadline. The original deadline was set for June 1, but Trump agreed to extend it to July 9, 2025. Trump stated on Truth Social that the Commission President assured him that negotiations would commence swiftly. Trump expressed his willingness to grant the extension, describing it as his “privilege to do so.” Von der Leyen said on X that she had a “good call” with Trump. She had requested time until July 9 to reach a “good deal.” Trump’s decision to extend the deadline follows his previous threat to impose a 50% tariff on all European Union imports.

title: How American Retailers Are Navigating Trump’s Volatile Trade Policy
content: Observer spoke with dozens of retail CEOs and founders, consumer experts and supply chain strategists about how they are navigating tariffs.
resumen:
In 2025, tariffs have emerged as a new "force majeure" for American retailers due to erratic tariff policies tied to Trump’s second-term agenda. Businesses are facing a high-stakes guessing game in navigating pricing, planning, and logistics, with trade alliances dissolving overnight and tariff schedules changing rapidly. Preserving optionality is now a survival skill.

Companies are reengineering operations and supply chains to withstand what many call a “Trump majeure.” Bill London, an international attorney at Kimura London & White, notes that businesses are revisiting contracts to insert renegotiation clauses and price adjustment mechanisms triggered by tariff shifts.

Charlie Youakim, CEO and co-founder of Sezzle, observes that pure e-commerce retailers, especially those reliant on Chinese manufacturing, are scrambling, reworking logistics, and repricing inventory. While there's no panic, there is urgency.

Ross Widmoyer, CEO of Faribault Mill, has embraced a hyper-local model, sourcing inputs domestically, which has provided insulation and agility. Faribault Mill employs around 100 people and brings in nearly $20 million in annual revenue.

Steve Skillings, founder of BusyBox, faces shutting down due to skyrocketing component costs from tariffs.

Jason Wingate, co-founder of Zlumber, emphasizes the need for structural flexibility, including diversified suppliers, agile freight partners, and manufacturing options.

Many companies have relied on China for manufacturing, but this reliance is becoming precarious. Lee Mayer, CEO of Havenly Brands, is skeptical of rapid re-shoring due to price hikes. David’s Bridal has restructured its global supply chain, shifting production away from China. Mattel has reduced its manufacturing reliance on China. Ben Koren, CEO of Frameology, re-shored production years ago.

Companies are responding in different ways: shifting production, building structural flexibility, leaning into innovation, or engaging in policy advocacy. Emily Hosie, founder of REBEL, is lobbying for tariff exemptions on baby products. Keegan Nesvacil, CEO of Woodland Tools, describes a “design-for-resilience” model.

Many large brands have opted to stock up on inventory.

Resilience now depends on agility, optionality, and the recognition that there’s no cookie-cutter playbook.

title: ‘The best chance we’ve got’: Can Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent save the world from trade Armageddon?
content: As President Donald Trump conducted an impromptu news conference in Doha, Qatar, this month, surrounded by business leaders and top advisers, he made a point of singling out one person in particular.
resumen:
En una conferencia de prensa improvisada en Doha, Qatar, el presidente Donald Trump destacó a Scott Bessent, Secretario del Tesoro, quien había asegurado un acuerdo para pausar temporalmente la guerra comercial entre EE. UU. y China. Trump elogió a Bessent, afirmando que los mercados escuchan cuando él habla. Bessent, conocido por su discreción, respondió que tenían un plan y un mecanismo para evitar la escalada comercial.

Bessent es considerado el funcionario económico más importante del mundo, siendo el principal negociador de Trump con China, liderando conversaciones comerciales con otros países y participando en la elaboración de un paquete fiscal y de gasto. También es responsable de mantener el papel dominante de Estados Unidos en el sistema financiero global.

Bessent se ha convertido en una figura clave en la administración, ganándose la confianza de legisladores, funcionarios y ejecutivos. Ha tenido éxito en luchas internas para consolidar su rol y es visto por Wall Street como la mejor esperanza para moderar las políticas económicas de Trump.

Antes de unirse a la administración, Bessent estudió la biografía de William McKinley, un ídolo de Trump en materia de aranceles. Aunque subestimó el entusiasmo de Trump por los aranceles, escribió a inversores que era poco probable que se implementaran aranceles generalizados al mismo tiempo que se abordaba la crisis migratoria.

Bessent, ausente de la Casa Blanca y los medios de comunicación durante una reunión de ministros de finanzas del G7 en Canadá, fue objeto de comentarios sobre su importancia. Trump anunció la recomendación de aranceles del 50% a la Unión Europea y del 25% a los iPhones de Apple. Bessent, en Nueva York, fue entrevistado en Fox News y Bloomberg TV.

Antes de ser Secretario del Tesoro, Bessent participó en una operación financiera exitosa en 1992, trabajando para el fondo de cobertura de George Soros. Su experiencia incluye estudios en Yale y el trabajo con Jim Rogers, quien lo introdujo al mundo de las finanzas.

En 2017, Bessent buscó entender la administración Trump, conectando con Steve Bannon para comprender la visión económica de Trump. Bessent donó a republicanos y mantuvo relaciones positivas en Wall Street.

Bannon considera a Bessent un jugador clave en la gestión del mercado de bonos. Cuando las conversaciones lideradas por Bessent con China llevaron a una desescalada arancelaria, Bannon defendió a Bessent.

Bessent tiene una relación de larga data con la familia Trump y ha sido un defensor de causas LGBTQ. En una entrevista, Bessent relató un momento en el Despacho Oval con su familia, donde presenciaron el trabajo del gobierno.

Bessent predijo la victoria de Trump en 2023, basándose en el análisis de las acciones que suben con las malas noticias. Su decisión de ayudar a la campaña de Trump se basó en su preocupación por la deuda de EE. UU.

Bessent ha influido en las políticas de Trump, como la pausa en los aranceles. Su enfoque en el rendimiento del Tesoro a 10 años es notable.

En la Conferencia Global del Instituto Milken, Bessent explicó que los componentes principales de la agenda económica de Trump (comercio, recortes de impuestos y desregulación) son partes interconectadas de un motor diseñado para impulsar la inversión a largo plazo en la economía estadounidense.

Los asesores económicos de Trump enfatizan que su agenda incluye incentivos fiscales y regulatorios, junto con los aranceles, para impulsar la inversión y el crecimiento. Los aranceles están diseñados para encajar en un marco más amplio que se centra en los recortes de impuestos y la desregulación.

La agenda busca equilibrar los incentivos fiscales y la desregulación con los aranceles, para evitar una recesión. Si alguno de estos elementos falla, la política económica podría colapsar.

title: Japanese Yen and Aussie Dollar Forecasts: Trade and Central Bank Pivots in Focus
content: AUD/USD climbs on tariff fears, but recession risks linger. RBA and Fed cues, US-China trade headlines, and Beijing policy in sharp focus.
resumen:
Trade tensions spike as Trump threatens 50% EU tariffs, sending USD/JPY down 1.01% on risk-off sentiment.
USD/JPY dropped below 143 on risk-off sentiment.
AUD/USD faces downside risk as US-China trade tensions may weigh on Aussie exports and RBA policy outlook.
Japan’s economy will be in focus on Monday, May 26, influencing the Bank of Japan rate path and USD/JPY trends.
According to preliminary data, the Leading Economic Index dropped from 108.2 in February to 107.7 in March.
A downward revision may temper bets on a Q3 2025 BoJ rate hike, potentially lifting USD/JPY.
A higher print could revive speculation of a Q3 hike, especially after April’s hotter-than-expected core inflation.
A more hawkish BoJ stance may drag the USD/JPY lower.
Economists had already pared back Q3 rate hike bets ahead of Friday’s inflation figures due to escalating tariff concerns.
A Reuters poll (May 7–13) showed: 67% of economists (39 of 58) anticipate no policy change in Q3, up from 36% in April.
52% forecast a 25-basis-point rate hike in 2025.
USD/JPY dropped 1.01% on Friday after President Trump threatened a 50% tariff on EU imports, boosting demand for safe-haven assets like the Yen.
Later in the session, Fed speakers will influence US dollar demand and USD/JPY trends.
Support for a Q3 2025 Fed rate cut could weigh on the US dollar and send USD/JPY toward the 140.309 support level.
Calls to delay rate cuts to assess inflationary impacts from tariffs may drive the pair toward the May 20 high of 145.507.
Bearish USD/JPY Scenario: Rising trade tensions, strong Japanese economic data, or dovish Fed rhetoric could drag USD/JPY toward 140.309.
Bullish USD/JPY Scenario: Easing trade friction, weak Japanese economic indicators, or hawkish Fed cues may lift USD/JPY toward 145 and potentially the 50-day EMA.
On May 26, US-China trade headlines and policy updates from Beijing will influence AUD/USD price action.
On Sunday, May 25, CN Wire reported that Chinese state media emphasized the unresolved nature of the US-China trade conflict, warning that talks would be “protracted and arduous.”
The commentary cited US delay tactics and the risk of renewed escalation if US political and economic pressures ease.
The report concluded that China must prepare for prolonged negotiations and a sustained confrontation.
A prolonged trade war may impact Aussie trade terms, given China accounts for one-third of Australian exports.
With a trade-to-GDP ratio above 50%, weaker demand from China could pressure the RBA into adopting a more dovish stance.
RBA Governor Michele Bullock recently warned that a worsening trade war could push Australia into recession.
She noted: “Australia’s economy could easily be compromised if a trade war between the US and China escalates… The market path is reflecting a possibility of a really bad outcome, pointing to a lower RBA cash rate.”
Rising recession fears and a more dovish RBA rate path may weigh on AUD/USD.
Bearish Aussie dollar Scenario: Renewed US-China tensions, Beijing withholds fresh stimulus, or dovish RBA cues may send AUD/USD toward the 200-day EMA.
Bullish Aussie dollar Scenario: Easing US-China trade tensions, Beijing stimulus, or hawkish RBA signals could send the pair toward the May 14 high of $0.65008.
Later today, US monetary policy will also affect AUD/USD.
Hawkish Fed rhetoric may widen the US-Aussie interest rate differential, potentially pulling AUD/USD toward the 200-day EMA.
Dovish cues favoring a Q3 Fed rate cut would narrow the rate differential, sending the pair toward $0.65008.
Traders should also monitor US fiscal risks and global trade rhetoric.
On May 23, AUD/USD rose 1.29% to $0.64914 as markets digested Trump’s tariff threat on EU imports and growing concerns over US debt levels.
Key Market Drivers to Watch Today: USD/JPY: US-Japan trade talks, Japanese economic data, and BoJ signals.
USD/JPY and AUD/USD: Fed speeches, US economic data, and global trade headlines.
AUD/USD: US-China relations, RBA commentary, and Beijing’s policy stance.

title: Trump Delays E.U. Tariffs Until July 9
content: President Trump said he would give the European Union more time to negotiate a trade deal before 50 percent tariffs take effect.
resumen:
President Trump said on Sunday that he would delay imposing 50 percent tariffs on all imports from the European Union until July 9 to allow more time for trade negotiations.

Mr. Trump said that he had spoken to Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, about his recent threat to enact the tariffs on June 1 if a trade deal could not be reached in the next week.

Mr. Trump has expressed frustration over negotiations with the E.U., saying that the union has been slow to offer trade concessions during a 90-day window to reach a deal that satisfies the administration.

On Sunday, Mr. Trump appeared to relent, at least for now.

“The Commission President said that talks will begin rapidly,” Mr. Trump wrote, referring to Ms. von der Leyen.

Ms. von der Leyen, in a separate social media post on Sunday, said that she had a “good call” with Mr. Trump and had conveyed to him that the E.U. needed extra time to reach a trade deal. She said that talks would advance “swiftly and decisively.”

The extension is the latest turnabout by Mr. Trump.

While announcing his recommendation for 50 percent E.U. tariffs on Friday, the president had assailed Europe’s negotiating tactics and expressed no interest in reaching a deal.

Friday’s threat of 50 percent tariffs came after Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent met with European counterparts as part of the Group of 7 meetings in Canada.

Mr. Bessent had given no indication to his counterparts that new tariffs were coming, but he defended them on Friday.

The Treasury Secretary said that Europe has a “collective action” problem and that individual countries in the E.U. did not know how Brussels was negotiating.

Mr. Trump’s tariff threat against the E.U. came weeks after he agreed to partially pause the 145 percent tariffs he had imposed on Chinese imports.

European officials held a call with their American counterparts for trade talks on Friday, and had earlier submitted a term sheet detailing their offers to secure a deal.

European leaders have offered to reduce tariffs on industrial goods to zero if the United States does the same, and to increase purchases of U.S. energy, among other commitments.

In a post on Truth Social Friday morning, Mr. Trump wrote that discussions with the European Union were “going nowhere” and that he was recommending a 50 percent tariff on European imports as of June 1.

Mr. Trump also threatened a 25 percent tariff on imports of smartphones made by Apple and other companies on Friday, saying they should be made in the United States.

Economists at Oxford Economics said that if implemented, the E.U. tariffs and the phone tariffs, combined, would reduce economic growth by 0.2 percentage points, raise inflation by 0.2 percentage points, and increase the unemployment rate by a tenth of a percentage point.

The economists, Ryan Sweet and Bernard Yaros, wrote that the proposed tariffs on the E.U. highlight a key forecast risk, whereby tariffs remain an ongoing tool to be wielded by the Trump administration whenever negotiations hit a snag.

title: Trump says he will delay tariffs on European Union until July 9
content: MORRISTOWN, N.J. — President Donald Trump said Sunday that he would delay tariffs that were set to be imposed next week on the European Union until July 9.

title: US-EU trade tensions 'to heighten economic uncertainty' as EU trade commissioner urges 'respect not threats' from US
content: Concerns over a US-EU trade war have been rising over the weekend as the US threatened to impose a 50 percent tariff on the EU and the bloc refused to back down, shaking global markets. The US-EU ...
resumen: US-EU trade tensions are rising as the US threatened to impose a 50 percent tariff on the EU, and the bloc refused to back down, shaking global markets. The US-EU trade tensions will add more economic uncertainty to the world, according to a Chinese expert. The EU trade commissioner, MaroÅ¡ Å efÄoviÄ, said any potential trade deal between Brussels and Washington must be based on "respect not threats." The US president claimed that "the EU, which was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the US on TRADE, has been very difficult to deal with," and recommended a straight 50 percent Tariff on the EU, starting on June 1, 2025. The US president later escalated his message to the EU - "I'm not looking for a deal," he said. The tariff threat came amid stalled negotiations, with Washington demanding unilateral concessions from Brussels to open up to US business, while the EU has been seeking an agreement that offers mutual gain. The US president's latest remarks follow his April 2 "Liberation Day" announcement of a 39 percent tariff on European goods. US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Friday he hopes a new tariff threat from the president would speed along talks with the EU regarding a new trade deal. In a Friday interview with Fox News, Bessent accused the EU of not engaging in "good faith" trade negotiations with the White House. Zhou Mi, a senior research fellow at the Chinese Academy of International Trade and Economic Cooperation, said the US seems eager to ramp up pressure on the EU, possibly due to growing concerns about its domestic economy. The S&P 500 lost 0.7 percent Friday and had its worst week in the last seven. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.6 percent, and the Nasdaq composite sank 1 percent. The benchmark STOXX 600 index was down 0.93 percent. Germany's DAX fell by 1.54 percent and France's CAC index slid 1.65 percent. The US was the largest partner for EU exports of goods in 2024, making up 20.6 percent of exports, according to Eurostat. Petroleum oils, medicinal and pharmaceutical products were the EU's most exported group to the US last year. Zhou said that the current unpredictability - driven by tit-for-tat rhetoric - is putting stress on businesses on both sides, including American companies. The French trade minister, Laurent Saint-Martin, said the US' new threats did nothing to help negotiations. Irish Taoiseach MicheÃ¡l Martin described the US proposal of imposing 50 percent tariffs on the EU as "extremely disappointing." Huo Jianguo, a vice chairman of the China Society for World Trade Organization Studies in Beijing, said the EU is one of the US' largest economic partners and remains a significant global power and the US' threat of a 50 percent tariff reflects its eagerness to reach a deal with the EU. A Harris Poll for Bloomberg News found that a majority of US adults, 56 percent, said their household finances would be better off if the US tariffs had not been implemented. The World Economic Situation and Prospects as of mid-2025 recently released by the UN mentioned that higher tariffs and trade policy uncertainty have weakened the global economic outlook for 2025.
