title: What is behind Donald Trump's 50% tariff on EU imports to the US?
content: What is behind the US president Donald Trump's 50% tariff on EU imports to the US? RTÉ's Washington correspondent Sean Whelan looks at the latest developments on both sides of the Atlantic as well as ...
resumen: Donald Trump announced a 50% tariff on EU imports to the US, which caused a reaction in financial markets. The policy shift came unexpectedly, with the tariff starting on June 1st. Trump stated that there would be no tariff if the EU built plants in the US. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the 50% suggestion was to speed up negotiations and force the EU to make a "high quality offer." Bessent also mentioned that the EU proposals have not been of the same quality as other trading partners. The US has accused the EU of not negotiating in good faith. The EU's approach is not to escalate tensions, engage in megaphone diplomacy, or try to remove emotion from the equation. The general EU tariff rate of 20% has been raised by Mr. Trump to 50%. Euro zone government bond yields fell sharply following Donald Trump's announcement. Trump said the EU has not treated the US properly and that they banded together to take advantage of the US. He also mentioned a $17 billion lawsuit from Apple. The US president also announced a 25% Tariff on Apple iphones, unless they are made in the USA. The EU needs to help the US find ground which they can easily take and then declare victory, before a real and deeply damaging trade war begins. The US is looking for fundamental change, and it is most unlikely - certainly not within the very tight negotiating deadlines the president has set. The two sides cannot even agree on the extent of the trade surplus the EU runs with the US. The EU side includes the trade in services, where the US has a big surplus that reduces the trade gap to about $150 billion in the EU’s favour. The Americans say the gap is more like $250 billion. The EU needs a more dynamic financial services sector. The EU has a whole book of detailed analysis and recommendations on the topic, one commissioned by the EU’s political leaders, the heads of state and government, called the Draghi report - after its author, former ECB President and former Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi.

title: Aranceles de Trump podrían obstaculizar solución a crisis en Haití
content: Problemas que ha creado el gobierno del presidente Trump con el mundo entero, especialmente con México y Canadá en materia de aranceles, pudieran ser serios obstáculos para que los países de la ...
resumen:
Los aranceles impuestos por el gobierno del presidente Trump, especialmente con México y Canadá, podrían obstaculizar la solución a la crisis en Haití, un tema que la Organización de Estados Americanos (OEA) podría incluir en su agenda.

El canciller norteamericano Marco Rubio, con miras a las elecciones de 2028, está enfocado en resolver la crisis haitiana, donde las bandas criminales afectan al país y a su régimen provisional.

Las dificultades entre Estados Unidos y México por los aranceles y la frontera común, influyen en el desinterés del gobierno de Trump hacia Haití.

La acreditación del nuevo embajador dominicano en México, Juan Bolívar Díaz, podría impulsar que México considere importante la solución del problema haitiano, que hasta ahora ha visto con desinterés.

México y Canadá son miembros de la OEA, pero lidiar con los aranceles de Trump y los problemas fronterizos hacen que la prioridad sea Estados Unidos.

El ministro de relaciones exteriores Rubio, con "línea directa" con el presidente dominicano Abinader, está prestando atención al tema haitiano y a las preocupaciones dominicanas.

La alternativa a la violencia en Haití sería el reforzamiento con tropas a la fuerza de pacificación liderada por Kenia, que no ha podido impedir el crecimiento de las bandas criminales.

La República Dominicana ha puesto en marcha un plan de expulsión de migrantes haitianos sin documentación, lo que ha generado un arma de doble filo al afectar la mano de obra en agricultura y construcción.

Se han levantado opiniones sobre la necesidad de regularizar la fuerza de trabajo haitiana y renovar los permisos laborales para evitar el encarecimiento de construcciones y productos agrícolas, ya que los obreros dominicanos no desean esos trabajos.

El capitán de empresas Frank Rainieri señaló que los trabajadores haitianos realizan trabajos que los dominicanos no quieren, como construcción, servicios domésticos y motoconcho, por lo que rechazar su presencia sin soluciones viables es insuficiente.

title: Illa sobre la guerra comercial: "La UE no tiene que temer a nadie más que a sus dudas"
content: Barcelona, 24 may (EFE).- El presdiente de la Generalitat, Salvador Illa, ha afirmado este sábado que ante la guerra arancelaria anunciada por el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, la Unión E ...
resumen: El presidente de la Generalitat, Salvador Illa, ha afirmado este sábado que ante la guerra arancelaria anunciada por el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, la Unión Europea tiene que "afirmarse" y "no temer a nadie más que a sí misma y a sus dudas e indecisiones". title: Trump y sus amenazas de aranceles, tema en semana de EEUU
content: Washington, 24 may.- La amenaza del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, de imponer aranceles a los productos de la Unión Europea (UE) y al gigante Apple, destacó en la agenda mediática de ...
resumen:
La amenaza del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, de imponer aranceles a los productos de la Unión Europea (UE) y al gigante Apple, destacó en la agenda mediática de la semana que finaliza.

Trump reactivó su guerra comercial tras sugerir que podría aplicar gravámenes del 50 por ciento a la UE, por la falta de progreso en los acuerdos comerciales, y del 25 por ciento para Apple si la producción de teléfonos móviles iPhone no se traslada a territorio estadounidense.

Trump afirmó: “¡Nuestras conversaciones con ellos (la UE) no nos están llevando a ninguna parte!”. Por lo tanto, recomendó un arancel directo del 50 por ciento a la Unión Europea, a partir del 1 de junio de 2025.

Los tres principales índices bursátiles europeos se precipitaron después de los comentarios de Trump, pues el DAX de Alemania y el CAC de Francia descendieron un 2,6 por ciento y un 2,8 por ciento, respectivamente. El FTSE de Londres bajó un 1,3 por ciento, mientras los futuros de las acciones de Estados Unidos también se desplomaron, en este caso los relacionados con el Dow Jones que cayeron más de 600 puntos (1,7 por ciento).

La actual propuesta de Trump significa que podría establecer una tarifa a la UE más del doble del arancel “recíproco” inicial del 20 por ciento que estuvo vigente en abril de forma efímera, antes de que dispusiera una pausa para las negociaciones, que expirará el 9 de julio.

Sobre los teléfonos apuntó: “Hace tiempo que informé a Tim Cook, de Apple, que espero que sus iPhone que se venden en Estados Unidos se fabriquen y construyan en Estados Unidos, no en India ni en ningún otro lugar”. “Si ese no es el caso, un arancel de al menos el 25 por ciento debe ser pagado por Apple a Estados Unidos”.

Otro tema de la semana fue la licencia administrativa que dio el Gobierno de Trump a más de un centenar de funcionarios del Consejo de Seguridad Nacional (NSC, por sus siglas en inglés) de la Casa Blanca. La medida es parte de una reestructuración dispuesta por el asesor interino de Seguridad Nacional y secretario de Estado, Marco Rubio.

title: DOJ and FTC Join Texas AG Paxton in Antitrust Suit Against Asset Giants Over Alleged Coal Market Manipulation
content: DOJ and FTC back Texas AG Paxton's lawsuit alleging collusion by BlackRock, State Street, and Vanguard in the coal market.
resumen: El Departamento de Justicia y la Comisión Federal de Comercio, brazos legales de la administración Trump, se están involucrando en una disputa contra gigantes financieros con el Fiscal General de Texas, Ken Paxton, a la cabeza. En la mira están BlackRock, State Street y Vanguard, acusados de esfuerzos colusorios en el mercado del carbón en busca de agendas de energía verde, a un costo, argumenta Paxton, para la independencia estadounidense y los consumidores. La demanda de Paxton, presentada en noviembre pasado, alega que al aprovechar su considerable influencia en el mercado, los principales administradores de activos conspiraron para reducir a la mitad la producción de carbón para 2030 al servicio de objetivos ambientales. Esta litigación fue reforzada recientemente por la intervención de agencias federales, con el apoyo del Departamento de Justicia y la Comisión Federal de Comercio a la causa de Paxton. El Fiscal General Ken Paxton, agradecido por el apoyo de la administración del expresidente Donald Trump, declaró: "Estoy agradecido de que la Administración Trump se haya unido a mi esfuerzo por responsabilizar a los principales administradores de activos por armar la industria financiera para controlar ilegalmente los mercados energéticos y forzar una destructiva ideología de 'energía verde' en el pueblo estadounidense". Esta demanda afirma que los acusados, a través de su supuesta manipulación, han disparado los costos de la electricidad para los hogares mientras engrosan sus propias arcas financieras. El quid de la cuestión, según Paxton, radica en el uso del poder de mercado para disminuir artificialmente la oferta, lo que desencadena saltos de precios y aprovecha los impulsos políticos bajo la bandera de la lucha contra el cambio climático. Se dice que las tácticas corporativas infringen varias regulaciones estatales y federales que tienen como objetivo prevenir las travesuras anticompetitivas y el comportamiento comercial engañoso. Para la industria del carbón y el sector energético en general, la demanda simboliza un retroceso crítico contra el peso de los inversores institucionales que dirigen las tendencias del mercado bajo la apariencia de inversión socialmente responsable, especialmente en lo que respecta a los recursos energéticos y su costo para los consumidores. "Juntos, el presidente Donald Trump y yo haremos que estas corporaciones rindan cuentas", afirmó el Fiscal General Paxton.

title: Trump’s wild tariff tactics risk giving everyone a bad case of burnout

The prez threatened a 50% duty on goods coming out of the European Union to begin next month, raging that trade discussions “are going nowhere,” and that the EU “was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the United States on TRADE.” Trump warned Apple that failing to move its manufacturing back home would prompt a tariff of “at least 25%.” In response, the Dow dropped 256 points in a volatile day. Luxury automaker Volvo warned that prices on cars are going to spike. 57% say that tariffs are hurting the economy; 26% think they’re the biggest mistake of Trump’s second term.

title: Guerra comercial: UE y fabricantes de teléfonos en la mira de Trump
content: El presidente de EEUU reactivó este viernes la guerra comercial con la amenaza de imponer aranceles a la Unión Europea, Apple, Samsung y otros fabricantes de teléfonos inteligentes.
resumen: El presidente de EEUU, Donald Trump, reactivó la guerra comercial con la amenaza de imponer aranceles a la Unión Europea, Apple, Samsung y otros fabricantes de teléfonos inteligentes. Trump insistió en que impondrá un 50% de aranceles a la UE porque las negociaciones no avanzan. Amenazó con sobretasas del 25% a todas las empresas que fabrican teléfonos inteligentes fuera de Estados Unidos, incluida Apple. Trump anunció en su red Truth Social que recomienda “imponer 50% de aranceles a la Unión Europea a partir del 1 de junio”. Trump dijo que todos los fabricantes serán impactados por esos aranceles, que entrarían en vigor a finales de junio. Trump amenazó con imponer aranceles de al menos 10% a la mayoría de los productos que ingresan a Estados Unidos. El comisario europeo de Comercio, Maros Sefcofic, sostuvo que la UE “está plenamente comprometida para llegar a un acuerdo beneficioso para ambas partes”. El primer ministro de Irlanda, Micheal Martin, consideró el anuncio como “decepcionante”. El ministro delegado francés de Comercio Exterior, Laurent Saint-Martin, escribió en X: “Desescalada, pero estamos listos para responder”. Trump amenazó a Apple con nuevos aranceles si no traslada a Estados Unidos la producción de celulares. Trump informó a Tim Cook (presidente) de Apple que espera que sus iPhones que se vendan en Estados Unidos sean fabricados en Estados Unidos. El secretario del Tesoro de Estados Unidos, Scott Bessent, dijo que la tasa mínima del 10% estaba “supeditada a que los países y bloques comerciales vinieran y negociaran de buena fe”.

title: Europe’s Been Negotiating by the Book, but Trump’s Tearing It Up
content: The Trump administration sees tariff talks as a chance to pressure a rival into concessions. E.U. officials have acted as though they were dealing with an ally.
resumen:
President Trump announced in a Truth Social post on Friday morning that he is recommending a 50 percent tariff on European imports as of June 1, claiming that the bloc’s trade barriers, taxes, corporate penalties and other policies had contributed to a trade imbalance with the United States that was “totally unacceptable.”

Mr. Trump wrote, “The European Union, which was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the United States on TRADE, has been very difficult to deal with,” adding, “Our discussions with them are going nowhere!”

The surprise announcement comes after months of back-and-forth talks between the two enormous economies.

Mr. Trump has imposed round after round of tariffs on the 27-nation economic bloc and the world since taking office in January.

In talks, the bloc’s policymakers have suggested what they have billed as win-win solutions, including a plan to drop tariffs on industrial products to zero and buying more American gas.

American negotiators have been looking for one-way offers, diplomats, officials and people familiar with the negotiations have said, and White House officials themselves have implied this is not a give and take.

Scott Bessent, the U.S. Treasury secretary, said on Fox News on Friday, “I believe the president believes that the E.U. proposals have not been of the same quality that we’ve seen from our other important trading partners.”

Mr. Trump wants European nations to nix their Value-Added Tax system, a key consumption tax — which negotiators say is not on the table.

Administration officials have suggested that they want Europe to change food sanitation standards so that it imports more American beef.

Administration officials have also come after Europe for its regulation of digital services and social media companies — also policies that European officials have been unwilling to reconsider.

Europe’s trading relationship with the United States is the largest in the world, by some measures. Nearly $5 billion in goods and services cross the Atlantic between the two partners every single day, by E.U. estimates.

The goods trade deficit was about $180 billion in 2023.

Maros Sefcovic, the E.U. trade commissioner, and his colleagues have traveled repeatedly to Washington to talk with Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, and Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative.

Mr. Sefcovic talked to his counterparts in the United States on Friday after Mr. Trump’s threat, and posted on social media afterward that “EU-US trade is unmatched & must be guided by mutual respect, not threats. We stand ready to defend our interests.”

The second set of countertariffs — which would target 95 billion euros-worth of American goods that could range from bourbon to soybeans — is still being refined.

“There are some countries that are impossible, like the European Union,” Mr. Lutnick said at an Axios event earlier this week.

The European Union currently faces 10 percent across-the-board tariffs on its exports, like other nations. After the 90-day pause expires in July, the bloc was expecting to face 20 percent tariffs, based on what the United States had previously announced.

“The president will decide if they’ve made us an offer worthy of modifying their tariff terms,” Mr. Lutnick said earlier this week. “If they haven’t made us an offer that modifies it, the president will write them a letter saying, ‘Dear country A, we deeply appreciate doing business with you. Here’s your tariff rate.’”

And, he said, “there will be no floor below 10.”

title: Daniel Noboa jura como presidente de Ecuador para el período 2025-2029
content: El presidente de Ecuador, Daniel Noboa, juró este sábado nuevamente como jefe de Estado para el período 2025-2029, en una ceremonia celebrada en la Asamblea Nacional (Parlamento) tras haber ganado las ...
resumen:
Daniel Noboa juró como presidente de Ecuador para el período 2025-2029.

La ceremonia se celebró en la Asamblea Nacional (Parlamento).

Noboa ganó las elecciones en la segunda vuelta a la candidata correísta Luisa González.

Se le impuso la banda presidencial y el Gran Collar de la Orden de San Lorenzo.

María José Pinto juró como vicepresidenta, reemplazando a Verónica Abad.

Noboa anticipó que también ocurrirá lo mismo con la corrupción y “con todas esas mafias que afectaban al crecimiento de los jóvenes y de las familias ecuatorianas”.

En la Asamblea Nacional (Parlamento) estuvieron delegaciones de 74 países, entre ellos los presidentes de Colombia, Gustavo Petro, y de Perú, Dina Boluarte.

Noboa fue elegido en 2023 para completar el periodo 2021-2025 que no culminó Guillermo Lasso.

Noboa dijo que su administración se ha trazado fijar lazos estrechos a nivel público y privado con la comunidad internacional para avanzar en el camino de la “apertura comercial y atraer inversiones que permitan aprovechar el verdadero potencial de Ecuador”.

Noboa enfatizó que “Ecuador se prepara cada día más para recibir inversionistas extranjeros con las puertas abiertas y claros”.

Noboa anticipó que mantendrá la “guerra” que desde 2024 lanzó contra el crimen organizado.

title: U.S. Exports Top $522 Billion, A Record Pace Being Set For 2025
content: Seven of the top 10 U.S. exports are at record levels. Not yet reflected in the government data are Trump’s April 2 tariffs on the world.
resumen:
U.S. exports totaled $522.61 billion through March, with seven of the top 10 exports at record levels. The two biggest winners through the first quarter are the primary aircraft category, up 20.59% to $34.32 billion, and LNG and other natural gases, increasing $5.70 billion to $21.79 billion, a 35.46% gain. The biggest losers are oil and gasoline, down 9.65% from the record pace of 2024, and passenger vehicles, down 6% from the record pace set in 2023. U.S. imports totaled $948.10 billion, and total U.S. trade came in at $1.47 trillion. The U.S. deficit stood at $425.49 billion. The balance of trade is down four percentage points from 2024, with exports accounting for just 36% of all U.S. trade this year. The top 10 exports accounted for 35.89% of the total.

The top 10 exports are:
1.  Aircraft, parts: up 20.59% to $34.32 billion.
2.  Oil: down 9.65% from the record pace of 2024.
3.  Refined petroleum: down 7.33% to $26.22 billion.
4.  LNG: increasing $5.70 billion to $21.79 billion, a 35.46% gain.
5.  Passenger vehicles: $13.83 billion, down 6%.
6.  Low-value shipments: a 1.09% increase to $13.67 billion.
7.  Vaccines, plasma: grew 6.06% when compared to the first three months of 2024, an increase of $768.02 million.
8.  Computer chips: a 27.56% increase to $13.30 billion.
9.  Computers: a 46.40% increase to $11.85 billion.
10. Gold: $11.55 billion, a 19.31% increase over the same three months of 2024.

Exports to China are down 72.35% for oil since the first quarter of 2018, down 72.60% for passenger vehicles since the first quarter of 2018, and down 39.53% for computers since the onset of the trade war in 2018. Exports to Germany since 2022 have increased 5.81 million percent.

title: Duro golpe de Trump: Cámara baja aprueba impuesto del 3,5% a las remesas de inmigrantes indocumentados en EEUU
content: El tributo a las remesas, que aplicaría para los inmigrantes en EE. UU., afectaría a millones de hogares en América Latina, particularmente en países como Honduras y El Salvador.
resumen:
La Cámara de Representantes de EE. UU. aprobó el “One Big Beautiful Bill Act”, que incluye un impuesto del 3,5% sobre remesas de inmigrantes indocumentados.
La votación fue de 215 a 214.
El proyecto abarca casi 900 páginas e incluye recortes fiscales, restricciones sociales, medidas de seguridad fronteriza.
La propuesta original contemplaba un gravamen del 5%, pero este fue reducido tras negociaciones.
La medida no aplicaría para estadounidenses, pues se enfoca en inmigrantes sin ciudadanía ni residencia permanente.
De ser aprobada en el Senado, esta medida marcaría la primera vez en la historia reciente de EE. UU. que se impone un impuesto a las remesas.
Expertos advierten que el impuesto podría tener efectos significativos en varios países centroamericanos, donde las remesas representan entre una cuarta y una tercera parte del Producto Interno Bruto (PBI).
El nuevo tributo se aplicaría a todos los migrantes que no cuenten con una "green card", incluidos quienes poseen visas temporales como las H-2B, F-1 o L-1.
En la práctica, esto significaría un cargo adicional de US$35 por cada US$1.000 enviados al extranjero.
La implementación del impuesto quedaría a cargo del Servicio de Impuestos Internos (IRS), que tendrá un plazo de 90 días tras la promulgación para definir cómo se comprobará el estatus migratorio en las transferencias.
En 2024, los inmigrantes enviaron más de US$160.000 millones desde Estados Unidos a América Latina y el Caribe, según el Banco Interamericano de Desarrollo.
Otras medidas impulsadas por Donald Trump en el paquete de leyes incluye que los inmigrantes pierdan los siguientes beneficios:
Crédito Tributario por Hijos (CTH): actualmente, niños ciudadanos pueden recibir hasta US$2.000 al año.
Subsidios de Obamacare: los subsidios para seguros de salud bajo la Ley de Atención Médica Asequible dejarían de estar disponibles para muchos inmigrantes legales.
Créditos educativos: el Crédito Tributario de Oportunidad Estadounidense de hasta US$2.500 y el Crédito de Aprendizaje Permanente de US$2.000 no serían válidos si no poseen un número de Seguro Social válido.
Exenciones en la deuda de préstamos estudiantiles: la deuda perdonada por discapacidad o fallecimiento no se considera ingreso tributable, pero esta exención quedaría restringida.
Restricciones a beneficios por ITIN: los inmigrantes que presentan impuestos con ITIN no podrían reclamar estos créditos.

title: Pivoting From Tax Cuts to Tariffs, Trump Ignores Economic Warning Signs
content: Since taking office, Mr. Trump has raced to enact his economic vision, aiming to pair generous tax cuts with sweeping deregulation that he says will expand America’s economy. He has fashioned his ...
resumen:
President Trump has ignored repeated warnings that his agenda could worsen the debt, harm the poor and contribute far less growth than the White House contends.

One day after House Republicans approved an expensive package of tax cuts, President Trump pivoted back to his other signature policy priority, unveiling a battery of tariff threats that further spooked investors and raised the prospects of higher prices on American consumers.

The decision to escalate his global trade war on Friday appeared curious and costly. It capped off a week that saw Mr. Trump ignore repeated warnings that his agenda could worsen the nation’s debt, harm many of his own voters, hurt the finances of low-income families and contribute far less in growth than the White House contends.

The president threatened 50 percent tariffs on the European Union, and a 25 percent tariff on Apple. Other tech companies, he said, could face the same rate.

Mr. Trump has raced to enact his economic vision, aiming to pair generous tax cuts with sweeping deregulation that he says will expand America’s economy. He has fashioned his steep, worldwide tariffs as a political cudgel that will raise money, encourage more domestic manufacturing and improve U.S. trade relationships.

So far, bond markets are not buying his approach. Where Mr. Trump sees a “golden age" of growth, investors see an agenda that comes with more debt, higher borrowing costs, inflation and an economic slowdown. Investors who once viewed government debt as a relatively risk-free investment are now demanding that the United States pay much more to those who lend America money.

Businesses, including Walmart, say they may have to raise prices as a result of the president’s global trade war.

The onslaught of policy changes has also left the Federal Reserve frozen in place, unsure as to when the economy will call for lower interest rates in the face of persistent uncertainty. As a result, borrowing costs for mortgages, car loans and credit cards remain onerous for Americans.

The White House released data showing that its tax cuts could increase U.S. output as much as 5.2 percent in the short term, compared with the gains it would have achieved if the bill is not adopted. The administration has stood largely alone in offering such rosy predictions about the effects of Mr. Trump’s policies on businesses, average workers and the nation’s fiscal future.

Economists this week predicted that Mr. Trump’s signature tax package could add well over $3 trillion to the national debt. Some found that the measure is unlikely to deliver substantial economic growth, and could enrich the wealthiest Americans while harming the poorest, millions of whom could soon lose access to federal aid for food and health insurance.

The tax cuts are largely an extension of ones that Congress passed in 2017, meaning that few taxpayers will see an increase to their after-tax income. Many of the lowest earners may even see about $1,300 less on average under the Republican bill in 2030, according to the nonpartisan Penn Wharton Budget Model, which factored in the proposed cuts to federal safety-net programs.

Stephen Miran, the chairman of the president’s Council of Economic Advisers, said in an interview, stressing that Mr. Trump’s agenda would “grow the economy.”

Eric Winograd, an economist at the investment firm AllianceBernstein, said: “It’s possible that you’re going to get a big benefit to growth, but the costs are so obvious and so clear that I think it’s hard to put a lot of faith in that at the moment.”

While economists do not expect the economy to tip fully into a recession, they say Mr. Trump’s tariffs in particular have raised the odds of a downturn, as both businesses and consumers begin to cut back.

Stephen Moore, a conservative economist who served as one of Mr. Trump’s advisers during his first term, said: “So many of these problems are the result of low growth.” Mr. Trump is aiming to get growth back up to 3 percent, Mr. Moore added.

The House Republicans voted to advance a bill that would extend the set of tax cuts enacted in the president’s first term. The measure also included Mr. Trump’s campaign promises to eliminate taxes on tips and overtime pay.

An analysis released Thursday by the Joint Committee on Taxation, a nonpartisan advisory arm of Congress, found that the new Republican measure may raise the average rate of growth in U.S. output by only 0.03 percentage points compared with current expectations through 2034. The joint committee also said the president’s tax package could add $3.7 trillion to the nation’s debt over the next decade.

Mr. Miran maintained on Friday that congressional analysts and others had underestimated the effects of Mr. Trump’s initial tax cuts, and had done the same this year.

Kevin Hassett, the director of the White House National Economic Council, said on Fox News on Thursday that there was “a lot of spending reduction in this bill,” adding that the Trump administration would seek additional savings as the bill moved through the Senate.

Moody’s Ratings downgraded the U.S. credit rating, citing Republican tax cuts and the proclivity of past G.O.P. administrations to spend.

Mr. Trump sent markets into another tailspin on Friday as he abruptly shifted his attention to tariffs. He attacked the European Union and threatened to raise tariffs on its exports to a flat rate of 50 percent. He signaled a mixed appetite for negotiations, telling reporters in the Oval Office: “I don’t know. We’re going to see what happens.”

The president also took aim at Apple, signaling he would impose a 25 percent import tax on iPhones. Mr. Trump later suggested his new tariffs might also apply to Samsung.

The S&P 500 fell nearly a percentage point on Friday and pushed the U.S. dollar lower against a basket of its peers.

Some companies, including Walmart, have said they may have to raise prices as a result of the president’s global trade war.

A report this week from Allianz found that many businesses are trying to push the added tariff costs onto suppliers or consumers, with roughly half of its survey respondents saying they may increase prices.

Austan Goolsbee, the president of the Chicago Fed and a voting member on this year’s rate-setting committee, told CNBC on Friday: “The bar for me is a little higher for action in any direction while we’re waiting to get some clarity.”

title: El 78% de las remesas se destinan a comida en Honduras
content: Los expertos consideran que una vez que sea aprobada el arancel, las familias hondureñas recibirán menos recursos ...
resumen: El 78% de las remesas regulares que reciben los hondureños se utilizan para gastos de alimentación, el 31.4% para la salud, el 30.1% para el pago de servicios básicos como agua y energía eléctrica, y el 17.6% en gastos de educación. Esto lo demuestra la Encuesta Nacional de Migración y Remesas Honduras 2023, del Instituto Nacional de Estadísticas (INE). Un impuesto del 3.5% a las remesas afectará a las familias que dependen de estos ingresos para subsistir. En manos del Senado de Estados Unidos está el proyecto de ley que incluye un impuesto del 3.5 % a las remesas enviadas fuera de ese país, impulsado por el presidente Donald Trump. Se estima que las remesas familiares para este año serán de 10,259.7 millones de dólares, según proyecciones del Banco Central de Honduras (BCH). El 98% de esa cifra, equivalente a $10,008 millones, provendría de Estados Unidos. Para la expresidenta del Colegio de Economistas de Honduras (CEH), Amparo Canales, si la medida es aprobada por el Senado en Estados Unidos, el impacto será negativo.

title: Trump carga ahora contra las empresas americanas: amenaza a Amazon, Apple y Walmart
content: Las grandes empresas de Estados Unidos, como Amazon, Apple, Mattel y Walmart, se han convertido en una de las dianas del presidente americano.
resumen:
Las grandes empresas de Estados Unidos, como Amazon, Apple, Mattel y Walmart, se han convertido en una de las dianas del presidente americano.

El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, anunció que aplicará un arancel del 50% a todos los productos importados desde la Unión Europea.

Trump amenazó a Apple de imponerles un arancel del 25% si la empresa estadounidense no traslada toda su producción a Estados Unidos.

Trump usó la misma red social para lanzar un mensaje similar a Walmart, donde prácticamente amenazaba a la multinacional si a esta se le ocurría aumentar los precios de sus productos como consecuencia de los aranceles aplicados a China.

Trump dijo: "Walmart debería DEJAR de culpar a los aranceles como la razón del aumento de precios en toda la cadena".

El director ejecutivo de Walmart, Doug McMillon, dijo que los aranceles impuestos por Trump eran "demasiado altos" y que "aranceles más altos redundarán en precios más altos".

El primer ataque se produjo el 29 de abril a la gigante multinacional Amazon.

La secretaria de prensa de la Casa Blanca, Karoline Leavitt, calificó la medida como un "acto hostil y político".

Trump llamó a Jeff Bezos, el dueño de Amazon, para quejarse de todo esto.

Trump amenazó con un arancel del 100% a Mattel, el fabricante de las muñecas Barbie o de los coches de juguete Hot Wheels.

Trump dijo: "Le aplicaremos un arancel del 100% a sus juguetes, y no venderá ni un solo juguete en Estados Unidos, que es su mayor mercado".

title: Trump’s E.U. Tariff Threat Could Cause Economic Damage Beyond Europe
content: A 50 percent tax on European imports would hit the continent hard, hurt the U.S. economy and slow growth globally.
resumen:
President Trump threatened to impose a 50 percent tariff on all goods coming into the United States from the European Union starting next weekend.

Agathe Demarais, a senior policy fellow at the European Council on Foreign Relations, stated that no one was expecting this and they don’t have a clue as to what it means.

Carsten Brzeski, chief eurozone economist at ING, warned that such tariff levels could lead to a combination of higher inflation and slower growth in the United States, potentially pushing Europe into a recession and causing global growth to fall.

Julian Hinz, a trade researcher at the Kiel Institute for the World Economy, calculated that U.S. economic growth would drop 1.5 percent.

The magnitude of this latest tariff is significantly higher than the 20 percent “reciprocal” tariff that Mr. Trump announced for the European Union in April and later paused.

Neil Shearing, chief economist at Capital Economics, said the scale of the increase in tariffs, the capricious manner in which they were threatened, and the growing size of U.S. budget deficits are unsettling financial markets.

Mary E. Lovely, an emeritus professor of economics at Syracuse University, said companies are already raising their assessments of the riskiness of investments in the United States.

Mr. Trump imposed high global tariffs and then quickly postponed them when the bond market shuddered. He threatened China with exorbitant tariffs of 145 percent. When China hit back with a 125 percent tariff on U.S. goods, Mr. Trump took a step back. Two weeks ago, the two governments issued joint statements that they would suspend the highest tariffs for 90 days and negotiate.

Maurice Obstfeld, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics and a former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, said that the Europeans have absorbed the message that if you hit back hard, markets will get nervous, and the president will back off.

European officials have prepared a raft of countermeasures in response to higher U.S. tariffs. Roughly a fifth of E.U. exports go the United States, and about the same share of American exports go to to the European Union.

The European Union has threated to put tariffs on the American services sector.

If Mr. Trump does end up imposing 50 percent tariffs on June 1, Ireland would be hit the hardest, with an estimated 4 percent decline in total economic output, according to Capital Economics. Germany’s gross domestic product is projected to shrink by around 1.5 percent, Italy’s by 1.2 percent, France by 0.75 percent and Spain by 0.50 percent.

Mark Blyth, a political economist at Brown University, said the policy swings coming out of the White House may simply depend on which adviser was the last to speak to the president.

In 2008, both the U.S. and Europe had the same size economies, but now, Europe’s economy is one-third smaller.

title: Trump threatens Apple with 25% tariff: Is now a good time to buy an iPhone?
content: In addition to promising a 50% tariff on the European Union, unless E.U. leaders come to an agreement with the Trump administration within approximately nine days, the president threatened Apple with ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump threatened Apple with 25% tariffs on any iPhone sold, and not made, in the U.S.

Trump posted on Truth Social, his social-media platform, on Friday: "I have long ago informed Tim Cook of Apple (AAPL) that I expect their iPhone's [sic] that will be sold in the United States of America will be manufactured and built in the United States, not India, or anyplace else."

Ming-Chi Kuo, TF International Securities analyst, said the costs would likely make such a move prohibitive.

A 25% tariff would mean hundreds of additional dollars on an iPhone price tag.

Prices for the iPhone product line start at $799 and go as high as $1,599 for the iPhone 16 Pro Max.

The iPhone 16 is powered by an "A18 Bionic" chip, integrates artificial intelligence into its camera control and has 85% recycled content.

Alex Kidman, who writes Alex Reviews Tech, said the iPhone 16's 60Hz screen at this price is "indefensible," and cited "inconsistent battery life and overly hot Qi2 charging.".

Some 36% of iPhone buyers in the 12 months ending December 2024 reported having their previous phone for two years or less, compared with 31% in the prior year.

The household savings rate in the U.S. fell to 3.9% in March from 4.1% in February. It averaged 8.4% from 1959 until 2025, reaching an all-time high of 32% in April 2020 and a record low of 1% in July 2005, according to Trading Economics.

Andrzej Skiba, head of U.S. fixed income at RBC Global Asset Management, said the environment surrounding Trump's trade approach may also ensure that borrowing costs remain elevated. "The Fed," he said, "won't likely be able to cut rates in this environment."

title: Can you get a stimulus check in 2025? Here's Trump stimulus check status update
content: Are we getting a stimulus check in 2025? Here's a status update on Trump stimulus checks and how to track your IRS checks by social security number ...
resumen: During the COVID-19 pandemic, the government approved three economic impact payments, or stimulus checks, in March 2020, December 2020, and March 2021. The opportunities to file or claim these stimulus checks have now passed. If you didn't get the full amount of the third stimulus check, you were eligible to receive the $1,400 Recovery Rebate Credit of 2021. The deadline to file for this last payment was April 15, 2025. Even if you received a tax extension, you still needed to file your 2021 tax return by the April 15, 2025 deadline to claim that last payment. There are no extensions or appeals available for missed deadlines, and any unclaimed stimulus payments become the property of the U.S. Treasury. While there have been rumors about a fourth stimulus check of $2,000, there has been no official confirmation from Congress or the IRS to support this claim. President Donald Trump said in February that he would consider a plan to pay out $5,000 stimulus checks to taxpayers in the form of a “DOGE dividend,” he has not shared any further specifics or details about the possible “DOGE stimulus” since then. Any form of stimulus payment has to be approved by Congress. That number was also based on the original DOGE goal of $2 trillion, which has since been revised to $150 billion. At a rally in Wisconsin in March, Elon Musk said that the checks may not come. New York is issuing checks between $150 to $400 to some households. California and Colorado are also sending checks to some taxpayers, according to Nasdaq. If you filed your federal taxes electronically and included your banking information, then you may expect a direct deposit within 21 days. If you did not include banking information, then you may expect a paper check refund via the mail within 6-8 weeks. Amended returns can take four weeks or more, and, if your return needs corrections or extra review, it could take even longer. You will know it is accepted once you see a "Refund Sent" alert when you check your tax return status online. Once the IRS approves your refund, it could hit your bank account within days via the direct deposit option. The IRS has an online tool called "Where's My Refund" that allows you to check on the status of your refund. You can start checking the status of your refund within 24 hours after you e-filed your current-year return. The refund information is updated on the IRS website once a day, overnight. The online tool requires you to enter your Social Security number, filing status and exact refund amount on the return. It will then respond with a return received (processing), refund approved (preparing to issue refund by date shown) or refund sent (sent to your bank or in the mail). The other way to check on the status is to call the IRS at 800-829-1954. If your taxes were electronically filed and accepted by April 15, it is estimated that you may expect a direct deposit federal refund from the IRS by May 6 or later if by mail. Most states have created dedicated online portals for tracking income tax returns. In most cases, you can check the status of your state refund by providing the tax year, your SSN or ITIN, and refund amount.

title: Hang Seng Index: Gains on PBoC Rate Cut and Easing Trade Tensions – Weekly Recap
content: Hang Seng extends gains amid PBoC rate cuts, easing US-China tensions, and tech earnings misses. Trade, debt, and policy risks stay in focus.
resumen:
China’s April retail sales slowdown led the PBoC to cut rates, lifting Hong Kong stock demand.
The Hang Seng Index posted its sixth consecutive weekly gain, supported by auto stocks but capped by tech losses.
Japan’s inflation rise and stronger Yen dragged the Nikkei 225 lower.
US markets fell in the week ending May 23 as renewed trade tensions and US debt worries triggered a flight to safety.
US President Trump recommended a 50% tariff on EU goods.
The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 2.47%, while the Dow and the S&P 500 dropped 2.47% and 2.61%, respectively.
10-year US Treasury yields soared to a high of 4.627% before settling at 4.509%.
Moody’s downgraded the US sovereign credit rating from Aaa to Aa1.
Economic data from China raised concerns about China’s economic momentum on May 19.
Retail sales growth slowed sharply in April.
The People’s Bank of China (PBoC) cut the 1-year and 5-year loan prime rates (LPR) by 10 basis points to 3% and 3.5%, respectively.
Easing US-China trade tensions also bolstered demand for Hong Kong-listed stocks.
CN Wire reported a meeting between China’s Vice Premier He Lifeng and JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon.
Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Ma Zhaoxu held a call with US Deputy Secretary Kurt Campbell on May 22.
The Hang Seng Index advanced 1.10% in the week ending May 23, marking its sixth consecutive weekly gain.
BYD Company Ltd. (01211) surged 7.14%, while Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd. (00175) gained 2.84%.
Alibaba (09988) sliding 3.73%.
The CSI 300 slipped 0.18%, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.57%.
Gold rallied 4.84%, closing the week at $3,356.66.
WTI crude oil fell 0.53% to settle at $61.375.
Iron Ore spot declined 1.44%.
The ASX 200 advanced 0.21% in the week.
The S&P/ASX All Technology Index climbed 1%.
Northern Star Resources soared 9.82%.
Commonwealth Bank of Australia rose 2.46%, while National Australia Bank advanced 1.86%.
The Nikkei 225 Index lost 1.1%.
Underlying inflation accelerated from 3.2% in March to 3.5% in April, while inflation ex-food and energy rose from 2.9% to 3%.
USD/JPY down 2.11% at 142.551 for the week.
Nissan Motor Corp. (7201) fell 0.81%, while Softbank Group (9984) and Tokyo Electron (8035) slid 3.43% and 3.03%, respectively.
Trump’s proposed EU tariffs will influence global sentiment.
Australia’s CPI and retail sales will impact RBA policy expectations and Aussie-listed stocks.
Japanese labor and retail figures may guide Yen direction and Nikkei momentum.
US GDP, inflation, and consumer confidence data will steer Fed rate cut bets and regional market trends, including the Hang Seng Index.

title: European plastics industry could suffer under Trump's threatened 50% tariffs
content: Plastics machinery could be "collateral damage" in a trade war between the United States and the European Union under new tariffs proposed to start June 1.
resumen:
President Donald Trump is threatening a straight 50 percent tariff on goods from the European Union starting June 1.

Trump said trade talks with the EU, which covers 27 member countries, aren't going anywhere in a May 23 post on his Truth Social network.

Trump posted that the EU was formed for the primary purpose of taking advantage of the United States on TRADE, and that the EU has trade barriers, Vat Taxes, ridiculous Corporate Penalties, Non-Monetary Trade Barriers, Monetary Manipulations, unfair and unjustified lawsuits against Americans Companies, and more, have led to a Trade Deficit with the U.S. of more than $250,000,000 a year.

Plastics News' Economics Editor Bill Wood noted that the trade deficit with the EU is closer to $250 billion than the $250 million in Trump's post — and that the U.S. has a trade deficit when it comes to plastics machinery.

Perc Pineda, chief economist of the Plastics Industry Association in Washington, said that imposing high tariffs on manufacturing inputs could raise production costs and hinder domestic manufacturing competitiveness in the near term.

Pineda said that for machinery that is no longer produced domestically, tariff rates should remain low.

The U.S. is the largest export region and investment location outside of Europe for the VDMA, a mechanical engineering industry association based in Germany with 3,600 members in Europe.

VDMA Chief Economist Johannes Gernandt said that the current blanket import tariffs of 10 percent on almost all product groups — including machinery and equipment — announced by the U.S. government in early April already was causing additional uncertainty in foreign trade.

Gernandt said that the USA is their largest single market and that new trade barriers come at an inopportune time.

Gernandt appealed to politicians to keep markets open.

Pineda said European companies should consider increasing value-added activities within the U.S. rather than relying solely on exports and distribution.

Wood said that a reset between the U.S. and its trade partners is long overdue.

title: Trump’s tariff threats clash with Apple iPhone's global supply chain reality
content: Trump told reporters later on Friday that the 25% tariff would also apply to Samsung 005930.KS and other smartphone makers.
resumen: President Donald Trump threatened on Friday to impose a 25% tariff on Apple for any iPhones sold, but not made, in the United States, as part of his administration's goal of re-shoring jobs. He expects the tariffs to go into effect at the end of June. The 25% tariff would also apply to Samsung and other smartphone makers. Trump had an understanding with Apple CEO Tim Cook that he wouldn't be doing this. Cook said he's going to India to build plants. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said the work of "millions and millions of human beings screwing in little, little screws to make iPhones" would come to the United States and be automated, creating jobs for skilled trade workers such as mechanics and electricians. Lutnick said Cook told him that doing so requires technology not yet available. Dan Ives, an analyst at Wedbush, said moving production to the United States could take up to a decade and could result in iPhones costing $3,500 each. Apple's top-of-the-line iPhone currently retails for around $1,200. Brett House, an economics professor at Columbia, said a tariff on iPhones would increase consumer costs by complicating Apple's supply chain and financing. Sally Stewart Laing, a partner at Akin Gump in Washington, said there's no clear legal authority that permits company-specific tariffs, but the Trump administration may try to shoehorn it under its emergency power authorities. Tim Meyer, an international law professor at Duke University, said in the administration's view, as long as he enacts the ritual of declaring an emergency and pronouncing it unusual or extraordinary, there is nothing a court can do.

title: Pro-Trump TV Ad Overstates His Second-Term Economic Record
content: A TV ad from a group supportive of President Donald Trump makes misleading claims, and uses outdated data, to argue that he is "fixing" an economy "ruined" by Democrats.
resumen:
A TV ad from a group supportive of President Donald Trump makes misleading claims, and uses outdated data, to argue that he is “fixing” an economy “ruined” by Democrats.

The ad says that “inflation and gas prices” are now “at four-year lows,” based on data from March. National average gasoline prices have increased since then and are several cents higher than when Trump took office. Economists have warned that inflation also may soon increase again because of Trump’s tariff policies.

The ad also says that “Trump’s plan” is to provide “middle-class tax cuts.” The Republican budget bill would benefit middle-income taxpayers by extending the 2017 tax cuts — on average, every income group would get some tax relief. However, a nonpartisan tax policy organization has found that the majority of the tax cut benefits would go to the wealthiest 20% of households.

Securing American Greatness, the nonprofit group behind the 30-second ad, paid in the “high seven figures” to run the commercial for two weeks in 20 targeted congressional districts nationwide, on cable TV and online. The ad started airing May 12.

The ad begins with a narrator saying that “they’ve ruined our economy,” as photos of Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, Rep. Nancy Pelosi and former President Joe Biden, all Democrats, are shown on screen. “President Trump is fixing it,” the narrator later says.

The economy wasn’t the best it’s ever been when Trump took office again in January – but it also wasn’t in ruin. Trump inherited an economy experiencing significant annual growth, monthly job and stock market gains, plus much lower inflation than in 2022. Gary Cohn, director of the White House National Economic Council during Trump’s first term, said in a December interview on “Face the Nation” that Trump was inheriting from Biden a “very stable economy.”

The ad’s narrator mentions “middle-class tax cuts.” The House-passed budget reconciliation bill would reduce taxes for middle-income households compared with what they would pay if the individual income tax cuts in a 2017 tax law are allowed to expire at the end of the year.

“Middle-income households would receive an average tax cut of about $1,800, or about 2.4 percent of their after-tax income,” according to Tax Policy Center estimates. Those households have incomes between about $66,800 and $119,200.

The TPC also found that “60 percent of the tax cuts would go to the top 20 percent of households and more than one-third would go to those making $460,000 or more.” The “biggest beneficiaries,” the TPC said, would be households making between $460,000 and $1.1 million, whose taxes would be reduced by an average of nearly $21,000, or 4.3% of their after-tax income.

The bottom 20% of households, who make about $35,000 or less, would get a tax cut of less than 1%, or about $160 on average.

An analysis of the budget bill by the Penn Wharton Budget Model says that the benefits disparity is even larger when factoring in the bill’s cuts to safety net programs like Medicaid and supplemental food assistance. According to PWBM, even when considering the bill’s tax relief, in the long-term “lower-income households and some in the middle class are worse off, despite positive economic effects.” The top 10% of the income distribution receives about 70 percent of the total value of the legislation.

The narrator of the ad claims that “we’re already seeing results” from Trump’s economic plan, as text on screen says “Trump’s Tariffs … Delivered Results.”

The quote attributed to the New York Times isn’t about results for the economy. The March 5 story highlighted in the ad was about tariffs that Trump announced this year on imports of Mexican goods that got Mexico to produce results for the U.S. on illegal immigration and fentanyl smuggling.

The Times reported that “Sheinbaum dispatched thousands of National Guard troops to the state of Sinaloa, the hub of fentanyl trafficking, where they seized vast amounts of the synthetic opioid and busted hundreds of laboratories.” Then she “sent thousands more” troops to the U.S. border, “contributing to a plunge in the number of illegal crossings,” the story said.

Mexico had “agreed to send more than two dozen alleged cartel heads to be tried in the United States,” reversing the Mexican government’s position on extraditions.

The ad’s narrator says that “the cost of living is coming down,” adding that “inflation and gas prices [are] at four-year lows.”

The ad refers to core inflation, which is a measure of the change in the price of goods excluding food and energy items. The April 10 Forbes article cited in the ad reported that the annual rate of core inflation was 2.8% in March, the lowest since March 2021. Core CPI was also 2.8% in April, the most recent data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The same Forbes article noted that tariffs that Trump implemented in early April, and ones that are currently on a 90-day pause, could end up increasing inflation again. It said that “Goldman forecasted the core CPI rate,” influenced by Trump’s tariffs, “would jump to 3.7% by the end of 2025, which would be a level not seen since March 2024.”

Average prices for regular gasoline are not at a four-year low. The claim appears to be based on a March 13 Inc article. Inc reported that average retail gasoline prices in early March “slid to a multi-year low, according to GasBuddy data.” At the time, GasBuddy, which tracks fuel prices, said that the national average cost had fallen to about $3.03 per gallon, “the lowest March level since the pandemic.”

As of the week ending May 19, the average price of gasoline nationally was about $3.17 per gallon, according to the Energy Information Administration. That was up from about $3.11 when Trump took office, according to EIA figures.

The ad’s narrator says “wages are up” while viewers see the words “hourly earnings increased,” which is a quote from the April 4 CNBC article cited in the ad.

CNBC reported that the one-month increase in average hourly earnings for private workers was 0.3% in March, the news outlet said that the annualized growth rate of 3.8% was the lowest level since July 2024. Then average hourly earnings increased 0.2% month over month in April, and, again, the year-over-year increase was 3.8%, according to the BLS.

As of April, average hourly earnings had increased 0.6% since Trump took office again.

The

title: Apple has had few incentives till now to start making iPhones in the United States
content: It would take several years and cost billions of dollars to build plants in the United States to make iPhones here. If that happens, prices could skyrocket.
resumen:
Apple has had few incentives till now to start making iPhones in the United States.
It would take several years and cost billions of dollars to build plants in the United States to make iPhones here.
If that happens, prices could skyrocket.
President Donald Trump threatened Friday to slap a 25% tariff on the popular device unless the tech giant starts building the product in its home country.
Apple has been building most of its devices in China, where it has invested tens of billions of dollars in massive factories that rely on a vast network of local suppliers.
Apple CEO Tim Cook said this month that most iPhones sold in the United States during March through June would come from India.
Cook said the trade war would end up costing the company an additional $900 million during the March-June period.
Industry analysts estimated the fees would drive up the cost of a $1,200 iPhone made in China to $1,500.
If Apple somehow could suddenly start making iPhones in the United States, prices for the devices would soar to at least $2,000 and possibly as high as $3,500.
The disincentives for Apple shifting its production domestically include a complex supply chain that Cook began to engineer in the 1990s while working for his predecessor, company co-founder Steve Jobs, who died in 2011.
It would take several years and cost billions of dollars to build plants in the United States.
The price of an iPhone could triple, threatening to torpedo sales of Apple’s marquee product, which brought revenue of $201 billion during the company’s latest fiscal year.
Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives estimated that the current $1,000 price tag for an iPhone made in China, or one made in India, would soar to more than $3,000 if production shifts to the United States.
Moving production domestically likely couldn’t be done until, at the earliest, 2028.
Ives predicted that Cook would engage in a “game of negotiations” with Trump that would spare the iPhone from the 25% tariffs.
As AI becomes more sophisticated, the technology might spawn a wave of hands-free and screen-free devices that lower demand for smartphones.
Apple executive Eddy Cue said this month during a trial about the Justice Department’s proposed breakup of Google for running an illegal monopoly in search, “You may not need an iPhone 10 years from now, as crazy as it sounds.”
Cook told investors tariffs had a “limited impact” on the company in the March quarter because Apple was able to optimize its supply chain.
Cook warned that it is “very difficult” to predict beyond June “because I’m not sure what will happen with tariffs.”
Many analysts are predicting Apple will raise iPhone prices come fall, when the latest models are typically released.
Apple continues to reap huge profit margins from the revenue generated by subscriptions and other services tied to its product, according to Forrester Research analyst Dipanjan Chatterjee.
That division collected $96 billion in revenue during Apple’s last fiscal year.
Apple can absorb some of the tariff-induced cost increases without significant financial impact, at least in the short term.
Apple is facing a significant decline in its service revenue after a federal judge recently issued an order prohibiting it from collecting commissions on transactions within iPhone apps that are processed on other payment systems other than its own.
Unless Apple prevails in an appeal, the decision could cost the company billions of dollars a year.

title: Trump threatens EU, Apple with tariffs over major gripe
content: Donald Trump has reignited his trade war with Europe — recommending a 50 per cent tariff on all goods — with the complaint that negotiations have been "going nowhere".
resumen:
El 29 de mayo de 2024, el Consejo de Ministros aprobó el proyecto de Ley de Eficiencia del Sector Público, que busca mejorar la gestión y el funcionamiento de las administraciones públicas. La ley se estructura en tres títulos:

*   **Título I: Medidas de eficiencia organizativa.** Incluye la creación de la Oficina Nacional de Supervisión y Evaluación de la Gestión Pública, que evaluará el desempeño de las entidades del sector público. También se promueve la simplificación administrativa y la colaboración entre administraciones.
*   **Título II: Medidas de eficiencia en la gestión de los recursos humanos.** Se establecen mecanismos para optimizar la planificación de plantillas y la gestión del talento en el sector público.
*   **Título III: Medidas de eficiencia en la gestión económica y financiera.** Se busca mejorar la gestión presupuestaria, la contratación pública y la utilización de los fondos europeos.

La ley se enviará al Congreso de los Diputados para su tramitación parlamentaria.

title: ‘There Is No Tariff’: Trump Denies Policy Shift After Calling for 50% EU Tariff
content: Just hours after President Donald Trump called for a 50% tariff on products from the European Union starting June 1, he told reporters “There is no tariff,” and “I’m not looking for a deal.” “The ...
resumen: President Donald Trump called for a 50% tariff on products from the European Union starting June 1, but later said “There is no tariff,” and “I’m not looking for a deal.” Trump wrote on Truth Social at 7:43 AM that the European Union has been difficult to deal with, citing trade barriers, VAT taxes, corporate penalties, non-monetary trade barriers, monetary manipulations, and lawsuits against American companies, leading to a trade deficit with the U.S. of more than $250,000,000 a year. He recommended a 50% Tariff on the European Union, starting on June 1, 2025, but there is no Tariff if the product is built or manufactured in the United States. A reporter asked Trump what he was hoping to achieve with a 50% tariff, to which Trump responded, “There is no tariff. What they will do is they will send their companies into the US.” Trump also stated, “I’m not looking for a deal. We’ve set the deal at 50%.”

title: Trump amenaza con nuevos aranceles a la UE y a los fabricantes de celulares
content: El presidente de EE.UU. planea imponer tarifas de hasta 50% a productos de la Unión Europea, a partir del 1 de junio; y del 25% a empresas Apple y Samsung ...
resumen:
El presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, renovó su ofensiva comercial con amenazas de aranceles de hasta 50% a los productos de la Unión Europea y del 25% a empresas de tecnología como Apple y Samsung.

Trump anunció en su red Truth Social que recomienda "imponer 50% de aranceles a la Unión Europea a partir del 1 de junio".

Los aranceles actuales están situados en una media de 12.5% (2.5% ya vigentes antes de la investidura de Trump y un 10% adicional desde abril de este año).

Trump denunció el déficit comercial de Estados Unidos con Europa, que estima entre 300,000 y 350,000 millones de dólares.

Según los datos del representante de la Casa Blanca para Comercio, el déficit comercial de Estados Unidos con el bloque europeo se elevó a 235,000 millones de dólares en 2024.

La Comisión Europea cuestiona esas cifras y habla de 150,000 millones de euros (unos $160,000 millones), y únicamente 50,000 millones de euros si se integra el excedente comercial estadounidense en términos de servicios.

Trump dijo que pese a sus reiterados pedidos, Apple no había trasladado la fabricación de sus iPhones a Estados Unidos, y amenazó con aplicarle a la empresa un arancel de "al menos" 25% si no nacionaliza la producción.

Trump amenazó con aplicar el arancel a la surcoreana Samsung y a otros fabricantes de móviles, si no mueven su producción a territorio estadounidense.

Apple se dispone a ampliar su cadena de suministro en la India a través de la construcción de una nueva planta valorada en 1,500 millones de dólares por parte de la taiwanesa Foxconn, su principal ensambladora, en medio de la guerra comercial entre Estados Unidos y China.

Las acciones de Apple perdían un 2.7% en los primeros intercambios.

Trump amenazó con imponer aranceles de al menos 10% a la mayoría de los productos que ingresan a Estados Unidos.

title: Stock market today: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq fall as Trump tariff threats roar back, US deficit anxiety deepens
content: Wall Street is assessing President Trump''s tariff salvo on Apple and what his giant tax bill means for the deficit and the economy.
resumen:
US stocks fell on Friday to register weekly losses. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) sank 0.6%. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) also fell roughly 0.7%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) backed off about 1%. All three major averages fell more than 2% for the week. The three indexes trimmed steeper losses that followed Trump's comment on Friday that Apple (AAPL) must pay a 25% tariff on iPhones sold but not made in the US. Apple shares fell about 3%. Trump implied the tariffs would apply to other cell phone manufacturers. Trump threatened to hike the tariff on EU imports to "a straight 50%" beginning June 1. The president's warnings shattered a more muted mood on Wall Street as investors wound down to the Memorial Day trading break on Monday. Stocks have suffered this week as deficit worries pushed up Treasury yields. The 30-year yield (^TYX) eased but held above the key level of 5% on Friday. Wall Street's attention has also begun to turn to Nvidia (NVDA) earnings, due Wednesday after the bell.

Stocks closed out the week in the red on Friday as renewed threats from President Trump against the European Union and iPhone maker Apple (AAPL) reignited concerns that the trade war is far from over. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) sank 0.3% for the session, but was down more than 2% for the week. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) and tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) also registered weekly losses of more than 2%. Shares of US Steel (X) skyrocketed more than 20% in the last half hour of trading on Friday after President Trump announced the American company will form a partnership with Nippon Steel of Japan. Apple shares fell nearly 3% after President Trump said the company must pay at least a 25% tariff unless iPhones sold in the US are manufactured domestically. Trump also threatened to hike tariffs on EU imports to "a straight 50%" beginning June 1. The market slumped this week as 10-year and 30-year Treasury bond prices declined.

Next week's trading will be shortened due to Memorial Day. The stock market will be closed on Monday. The big focus next week will be on Nvidia (NVDA). The AI chip giant will report its earnings on Wednesday, after the bell.

President Trump reiterated his demand that Apple (AAPL) — and potentially other smartphone manufacturers — produce devices in the United States if they intend to sell them domestically. Otherwise, they could face tariffs. Apple (AAPL) stock fell more than 2% mid-morning Friday after President Trump said the company faces at least a 25% tariff, unless its iPhones sold in the US are made domestically. Tesla (TSLA), Meta (META), Alphabet (GOOGL, GOOG), Amazon (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT), and Nvidia (NVDA) all declined roughly 1% during the session.

Nuclear stocks rallied after President Trump signed executive orders to revive the industry. Nuclear-related stocks Oklo (OKLO), Constellation Energy (CEG), and Nano Nuclear (NNE) all rose by double-digit percentages.

Solar stocks rebounded on Friday but were still on track to close out the week with steep losses. SolarEdge (SEDG), Sunrun (RUN), Complete Solaria (SPWR), and Enphase Energy (ENPH) were among the biggest decliners this week, all down double-digit percentages.

Bitcoin (BTC-USD) dropped nearly 2% from its recent record high to hover near $109,000. Crypto-related stocks also sank on Friday. Shares of Strategy (MSTR) dropped more than 3%. Mara Holdings (MARA) and Riot Platforms (RIOT) dropped more than 5% and 3%, respectively.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) sank 1%, or over 400 points. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) fell 1.3%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) backed off 1.2%. Apple shares sank after Trump said the iPhone maker would face at least 25% tariffs if it did not make its iPhones sold in the US domestically. He also threatened to hike the tariff on EU imports to "a straight 50%" beginning June 1.

Volvo Cars (VOLCAR-B.ST) warned that it's customers may have to pay a large part of the company's tariff related cost increases. Shares in the company fell over 4%.

Europe's broad Stoxx (^STOXX) 600 index fell as much as 2% before recouping some of those losses.

Futures on the Dow Jones Industrial Average (YM=F) dropped 1.4%, or nearly 600 points, while those tied to the S&P 500 (ES=F) fell 1.6%. Contracts on the tech-heavy Nasdaq 100 (NQ=F) sank 1.9%.

Shares of nuclear power companies soared in premarket after Reuters reported that President Trump will soon sign executive orders aimed at jump-starting the nuclear energy industry. Shares of Oklo (OKLO), a nuclear start-up backed by OpenAI's Sam Altman, surged 19%. Other big gainers included Nano Nuclear Energy (NNE) and NuScale Power (SMR), both up around 17%. Among nuclear utilities, Constellation Energy (CEG) put on 5%, Vistra (VST) gained 4%, and GE Vernova (GEV) added 3%.

Deckers Outdoor (DECK) said late Thursday it won't provide annual guidance because of uncertainty around the economic impact of US tariffs. The maker of Hoka and UGG footwear also posted a disappointing quarterly sales forecast, helping drive its shares 17% lower in premarket.

The yield on the 30-year Treasury (^TYX) has risen above 5%.

title: Trump abandona a Europa.
content: De agresor a mediador. Los señores de la guerra que forman parte de la OTAN-EU se han quedado sin su principal promotor de la guerra proxy Rusia-Ucrania, su socio, Estados Unidos, representado por el ...
resumen:
Donald Trump, el nuevo presidente de Estados Unidos, ha transformado la política de su país de ser agresor a mediador, abandonando a Europa y a la OTAN en su propósito de derrotar militarmente a Rusia.

Trump ha manifestado que la guerra que empezó "el estúpido presidente Joe Biden" no es su guerra, que su agenda tiene otras prioridades y objetivos estratégicos para hacer más grande a Estados Unidos, que no va a jugar a la guerra poniendo al mundo al borde de una guerra nuclear, y que hay que pagarle la inversión norteamericana en la guerra mediante un contrato de explotación y manejo de las tierras raras.

También ha declarado que Ucrania jamás pertenecerá a la OTAN, que la Unión Europea tiene que asumir su propia defensa gastando el 5% del PIB en armas para su seguridad, y que Europa tiene que equilibrar su balanza de pagos, o impondrá aranceles prohibitivos.

Trump ha ordenado el desmantelamiento de la USAID, un brazo político de la CIA, especialista en aplicar golpe suave a través de revoluciones de colores y la Primavera Árabe, y espera un acuerdo de paz que le permita hacer negocio con Rusia, en la explotación de las tierras raras de Ucrania, del Ártico y de recursos naturales de la Federación Rusa.

title: Amenazas de Trump de nuevos aranceles sacuden los mercados: ahora le toca a Apple y la Unión Europea

title: Trump firma ordenes ejecutivas para impulsar el desarrollo de la energía nuclear
content: El presidente de EE.UU., Donald Trump, firmó este viernes tres órdenes ejecutivas que buscan impulsar el crecimiento de la energía nuclear en su país, lo ...
resumen: El presidente de EE.UU., Donald Trump, firmó este viernes tres órdenes ejecutivas que buscan impulsar el crecimiento de la energía nuclear en su país, lo que incluye el desarrollo de nuevos tipos de reactores compactos, incrementar la producción de combustible o aumentar las exportaciones del sector. Una de las órdenes busca atajar la futura demanda energética que se espera que tengan en EE.UU. los sectores de inteligencia artificial (IA) y defensa y para ello acelerará los procesos regulatorios para el desarrollo y la adopción de nuevos tipos de unidades de fisión, como los llamados reactores modulares pequeños (SMR por sus siglas en inglés), que aún no tienen uso comercial. Este edicto también crea un puesto de enviado especial para la exportación de tecnología nuclear e insta al Departamento de Energía a aprobar marcos para que aumente el enriquecimiento de uranio en EE.UU., país que obtiene del exterior más de un tercio de su combustible atómico. La segunda orden ejecutiva busca reformar la Comisión Reguladora Nuclear (NRC) para eliminar lo que la Administración Trump considera barreras para la construcción y uso comercial de reactores atómicos «con el objetivo final de cuadruplicar la producción de energía nuclear en las próximas dos décadas y media». A su vez, la tercera orden ejecutiva incluye la invocación de la llamada Ley de Producción de Defensa para impulsar la cooperación con el sector privado de cara a garantizar el futuro suministro de combustible nuclear. Las tres órdenes «permiten realizar pruebas de diseño de reactores en los laboratorios del Departamento de Energía, allanan el camino para la construcción (de plantas) en suelo federal para proteger la seguridad nacional y económica y eliminan las barreras regulatorias al requerir que la NRC emita licencias de manera oportuna», explicó la Casa Blanca en un comunicado posterior.

title: US Stock Market Highlights: US steel surges 21% after Nippon merger approval
content: US stocks fell as Trump targets Apple and EU with tariffs. Dow Jones dropped 181 points, S&P 500 and Nasdaq also fell. Apple shares declined over 2%.
resumen:
US Steel shares soared 21% on Friday after Donald Trump approved its merger with Japan’s Nippon Steel.

US stocks fell on Friday due to renewed trade tensions after President Trump targeted Apple and the EU. The Dow dropped 181 points, S&P 500 and Nasdaq fell 0.4% and 0.7%. Apple shares fell over 2%.

President Donald Trump declared that iPhones sold in the United States must be manufactured domestically—or face a minimum tariff of 25%.

Trump also signalled that trade talks with the EU had stalled, calling for a flat 50% tariff on all EU imports from 1 June 2025.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average shed 181 points, or 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite each dropped 0.4% and 0.7%, respectively.

Tech giant Apple saw its shares fall over 2%.

Following Donald Trump’s renewed trade threats, markets tumbled on Friday.

Booz Allen Hamilton shares tumbled 15% after the consultancy announced plans to cut around 2,500 jobs – 7% of its workforce.

Intuit surged 7.5% after posting strong quarterly results. The firm, which owns TurboTax and QuickBooks, reported a 15% year-on-year revenue rise in its fiscal third quarter, reaching $7.8 billion.

Apple fell 2.6% after President Trump warned the company could face tariffs of 25% or more on iPhones manufactured outside the US.

Apple shares slipped on Friday, pushing its market capitalisation back below the $3 trillion mark.

Three S&P 500 stocks notched fresh record highs: Philip Morris, GE Vernova, and Intuit.

Three names in the index slipped to new 52-week lows: CarMax, Campbell Soup, and Kraft Heinz. Revvity also declined to its lowest since December 2023.

The White House believes financial markets may be overreacting to President Donald Trump’s recent tariff comments.

US new-home sales unexpectedly jumped nearly 11% in April to a 743,000 annual rate.

Chinese EV giant BYD has overtaken Tesla in European battery electric vehicle sales for the first time, despite steeper EU tariffs. April sales surged 359% year-on-year.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average was trading 400 points lower, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite too were trading in the red at 60 and 260 points, respectively, at around 7.04 pm IST.

US-listed shares of Deutsche Bank dropped 5.1%, while HSBC and ING each slipped around 2%. Banco Santander lost 1.9%, and luxury giants LVMH and Hermès also traded lower. The Stoxx Europe 600 index was last down 1.5%.

The yield on the 30-year US Treasury bond reached 5.161% this week, marking its highest level since October 2023. The 10-year note also briefly exceeded 4.6%.

Apple shares dropped 3.5% in premarket trading after President Donald Trump declared the company would face tariffs of 25% or more on iPhones produced outside the US.

Nuclear-related stocks rallied after reports suggested Trump is poised to sign executive orders supporting the sector. Oklo and NuScale each jumped over 8%, while Constellation Energy and Cameco climbed 2% and 4% respectively.

Intuit surged nearly 8% after issuing a strong full-year forecast. The firm now expects adjusted earnings between $20.07 and $20.12 per share.

NuScale, Oklo, Constellation Energy, and Cameco all posted significant gains.

Apple has increased trade-in values for iPhones in China.

The Dow is down 500 points, S&P is at -90 points, and Nasdaq is trading 400 points down.

Donald Trump has proposed a 50% tariff on goods from the European Union.

The Dow is down 500 points, S&P is at -70 points, and Nasdaq is trading 300 points down.

Apple shares dropped 3% in pre-market trading on Friday after US President Donald Trump declared on Truth Social that a 25% tariff “must be paid by Apple” on iPhones sold in the US but manufactured abroad.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average futures dropped 112 points (0.3%), with the Nasdaq 100 and S&P 500 futures also falling 0.4% and 0.3% respectively. Apple shares were caught in the crossfire, down 0.36%.

title: El mercado de las criptomonedas se alista para afrontar el impacto de las tensas negociaciones comerciales globales de Trump.
content: El mercado de las criptomonedas vive momentos de incertidumbre ante las negociaciones tarifarias de Trump Las criptomonedas han experimentado una caída significativa en medio de nuevas tensiones comer ...
resumen: El mercado de las criptomonedas vive momentos de incertidumbre ante las negociaciones tarifarias de Trump. Las criptomonedas han experimentado una caída significativa en medio de nuevas tensiones comerciales entre Estados Unidos y la Unión Europea. La decisión del presidente Donald Trump de proponer aranceles del 50% ha generado nerviosismo en el mercado, repercutiendo en la cotización de activos digitales como Bitcoin y Ethereum. El Bitcoin (BTC), que recientemente alcanzó un máximo histórico de 111,814 dólares, sufrió una caída del 4%, seguida por Ethereum (ETH), que vio una disminución del 3.2% después de que Trump publicara en Truth Social que las negociaciones con la UE «no estaban llevando a ninguna parte». Más de 300 millones de dólares en posiciones apalancadas fueron liquidadas. Trump ha hecho la propuesta de imponer un arancel del 50% sobre las importaciones de la UE, así como un 25% específicamente sobre los iPhones producidos en el extranjero. La expiración de la pausa tarifaria en julio ejerce presión sobre las negociaciones en curso. Ethereum (ETH) no ha escapado a la volatilidad del mercado, manteniendo un nivel de soporte en 2,500 dólares, pero enfrentando dificultades para superar la resistencia de 2,700 dólares, con pérdidas diarias extendiéndose, también, al 4%. La popular criptomoneda Pi Coin mostró signos de crecimiento a principios de este mes, pero no logró sostener sus ganancias después de caer por debajo de 1.23 dólares. Las acciones de empresas tecnológicas en EE.UU. también han reflejado el descenso de las criptomonedas, con Apple experimentando caídas. La implicación personal de Trump en el sector de las criptomonedas ha añadido una capa inesperada de controversia, destacándose en un gálano muy mediático para los principales poseedores del memecoin TRUMP. Tras el gala, el token TRUMP vio un incremento hasta alcanzar los 16 dólares para luego caer a 13.81 dólares.
